TALK.START.PARA: —I regard his departure as a loss because during last year he was very actively engaged with the current Chairman of Committees and with me in trying to devise ways to get greater Senate adherence to the view that we should refer more of our legislation to standing committees. It was his strongly held view that the Senate's legislative role could be enhanced in that way. As I mentioned earlier, enthusiasm for that tends to be rather modest among Ministers of the day and even government senators of the day and I regret that he will not be here with us to pursue that line over the coming years because I am sure that it is going to require years of application to bring about change.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that a number of other Opposition senators wish to say something about Senator Rae. I would like to mention just a couple of other things which I think were reasonably notable features of a distinguished parliamentary career. In terms of his contribution to Liberal Party thinking, I have a particular affection and regard for the work he did in 1974-75 when he was our spokesman on Aboriginal affairs. During that time and during the time of the subsequent spokesman, Mr Bob Ellicott, we actually achieved a high degree of bipartisanship of policy in an area where I think bipartisanship of policy is particularly valuable. The lack of bipartisanship over the last eight or more years has I think been a significant problem in that area for both the previous Government and the present Government. Without wishing to canvass in any way the merits of those years, I simply pay tribute to the fact that Senator Rae contributed in a quite important way in 1974-75 both while he was spokesman and subsequently to achieving a position where there was for perhaps three or four years a high degree of unanimity and I think a good deal of progress in that quite difficult area.

Another notable feature of Senator Rae's approach to matters in this chamber which I think will always be remembered was his obviously great affection for his home State. I do not think that anyone would deny that Senator Rae had a public reputation on two bases-one, that he was a senator and, secondly, that he was a Tasmanian. I was struck from my earliest time here by the depth of his affection for his home State and by his strong belief that it had a great future and that tourism would play a very important part in that future, and I think that things that have occurred over recent years in Tasmania bear out his faith and the views which he expressed so vigorously.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he is still alive and well.

—My colleague has reminded me that he is still alive. If this is starting to sound like a condolence motion, I can only assure honourable senators opposite that the few remaining Labor members of the Parliament in Tasmania will, I am sure, be feeling the edge of his tongue very soon. They will be very certain that Senator Rae is alive and well. Certainly the Opposition Labor members of Parliament in Tasmania will dearly wish that Peter Rae was back with us in the Senate rather than giving them curry in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Opposition I wish Peter Rae all the best for a new career in politics in his home State of Tasmania. Having just made the air trip to Canberra yet again I can only say that I envy him the fact that he will be operating close to his home. I am sure that he will bring the same vigour and enthusiasm to his work in Tasmania as he has brought to his work in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I too pay tribute to the service that Peter Rae has given to his country over a number of years-in fact since 1967 when he was elected. He entered the Senate in 1968. I pay tribute on behalf of my Party-the Australian Democrats-but more particularly on my behalf because Peter Rae and I have been close friends. I use those words advisedly because it has been my observation, after having spent 25 years in politics, that notwithstanding the closeness that we find with one another very few real friendships are formed in politics, either among members of parties or across party lines. I do not know the reason for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we have close acquaintanceships and there are a great number of our colleagues on both sides of the chamber for whom we have affection. However, very few real friendships are formed. The test of a friendship is whether, when one gets out of this place, one would love to have a member or senator and his spouse to one's house for dinner. That is the sort of friendship I am talking about. Whether it is because of the competitiveness of politics, whether it is one of the few professions in which one can advance only at the expense of a mate, I do not know: But from my observation it is a fact of life. Peter Rae and I broke that rule. We have been close personal friends. I believe that we have had mutual admiration and respect for one another for more than 20 years. I admire his courage. He has had lots of kicks in the guts in his political career. He has taken them; he has copped them. However, what is even greater about the man is the fact that the loyalty he has shown to the people who have given him those kicks in the guts and the Party has been astonishing. I do not want to embarrass Peter but if anyone had an unanswerable reason to leave the Liberal Party of Australia and to say `You can go to hell; I have given you the best I have' it was him. But I have not heard him publicly or privately whinging or complaining about the deal he got. In fact after he got those shoddy deals he worked twice as hard for the Party which he saw gave him a position of eminence in the community. I have nothing but admiration for him and I wish him well.

It is not the best kept secret in Canberra that he will be offered a senior post in another institution in this country. I compliment the Premier of Tasmania-that in itself is a rare event-for having the wisdom that I believe Mr Howard did not have in offering Mr Rae a job. Whatever he is offered-I hope it will be in the fields of endeavour in which he has distinguished himself in this place; in areas of industry and commerce-I know that he will acquit himself well and be a credit to his Party.

I would like to put on the record something a little less personal about Peter Rae, but I think it ought to be said. He put more time and effort than anyone else into the development of the Senate committee system and the legislative review function of the Senate as an institution. I think if one joins together the names of Peter Rae and Lionel Murphy-we ought to do that quite often when we think of the tremendous status--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am determined that you all should not.

—I am prepared to give credit where credit is due. I think that, in their different ways, those two men lifted the Senate and the Senate committee system to a new level of public acceptability and public service. As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, Senator Peter Rae was responsible for drawing public attention to the value of the committee system in the Senate. His work on the subject of statutory authorities revealed the extent to which statutory authorities were not accountable, and the nature of that. As a result of these revelations, the accountability of such bodies has been improved. When Peter Rae first sat on Estimates committees, they had to dig up every bit of information for themselves. Over a time he and others helped to persuade governments to issue explanatory memoranda in a standardised form, and these memoranda are of enormous assistance to all members of parliament and, in particular, to my Party, which has to scrutinise every clause of every piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are just a few of the accomplishments of Senator Peter Rae. We will all miss him, not only for his service but also for the happy, good humoured approach he took to crises and to people, and we wish him well because he is a damned good bloke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would also like to join my colleagues, on behalf of the National Party of Australia, first of all in welcoming Senator Coleman back after her long illness. I have served both with Senator Coleman and under her chairmanship of Senate standing committees. One might say we are poles apart philosophically but, still, we have had a good rapport and a respect for each other's position. It is good to welcome her back after that long illness. Secondly, I join in the comments made about our former colleague, Senator Rae, who, I say at the outset, has gone on to what he would consider greener pastures. As has been indicated, the only time one gets to say anything really complimentary about one's colleagues, on either side of the chamber, is either when they leave this place or by way of eulogy. This is one of the more pleasant occasions, in that it is about a colleague leaving this place and going to a State parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The speakers before me have indicated Peter Rae's role in the committee system of this Senate and, indeed, it would be fair to say that Peter Rae's contribution enhanced that system. I suppose that the committee that made his name known to the Australian people was the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. Quite significantly, as well as being Chairman of it whilst his Party was in power, he maintained that chairmanship when he went into opposition, such was his standing amongst his colleagues and amongst the community. Of course, anyone who follows the parliamentary system in Australia fully realises that the Senate committee system is held in high regard in this country.

So, on behalf of the National Party, I say that we are pleased to have served with Peter Rae in this chamber, to have learnt from him, particularly in respect of the committee system and the Standing Orders of this chamber, and we wish him well even though we would not necessarily agree that he has gone to greener pastures. Undoubtedly, in his mind, he has. We wish him well and we hope that he thoroughly enjoys them and makes an equal contribution in his new role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I also welcome back my colleague Ruth Coleman. It is good to see her looking so fit. I would like to say a few words regarding ex-Senator Peter Rae, as I am also a senator from Launceston. The first thing I would like to say is that, coming up in the plane from Launceston on Sunday last, I also envied Peter Rae. I can understand what he is about-no longer having to travel around the way he has and we all have in the past, no longer having to wake up in motel rooms so often. I think that he will think it is more than just greener pastures, Senator Collard. As others have said, Peter Rae has a deep and abiding love for Tasmania. He will now be able to carry out his second love, or his third love after sailing, which is politics, and yet stay in the State and not have to travel around the way he has been.

SPEECH.PARA: Being a senator from Launceston, I quickly became acquainted with Senator Peter Rae when I was elected to this place. We quickly came to an arrangement that on Tuesday mornings we would both get the same plane, so that if it was held up by fog, as it frequently was, we both would not need pairs; we just both were not here together. We had very considerable differences on politics; we had very considerable differences on the role of this place. But one could not but have respect for Peter Rae, first of all because of his courage. Not many of us will forget-he may wish that we would forget-that he was opposed to the construction of the dam in Tasmania. I will never forget those ads in the paper during the last Senate election campaign, when what I would call the troglodytes had in the paper ads saying `Vote Liberal' but conspicuously leaving Peter Rae off the top of the ticket. They opposed him vigorously but he stuck to his guns, to a view which he held on economic grounds and a view which I believe has been demonstrated to be perfectly accurate and true.

The second thing I remember of Peter Rae is his and my bipartisan efforts to do something about Tasmanian air services and the Launceston Airport. Unfortunately, in this regard we failed because of opposition from other parliamentarians from both sides of politics who believed that the best thing for Launceston was to maintain the status quo and that the best thing for Tasmania was to maintain the status quo. It is with some regret, when I come back home after working a day in Sydney, that I find that I have to fly to Devonport rather than Launceston. When I see the lack of ambition and lack of courage of the Launceston business community in opposing local ownership of Launceston Airport, I regret that both Peter Rae and I did not succeed in that regard.

There is one final thing I would like to say. Politicians from small cities, small towns and small States frequently have to put up more than others, perhaps, with the sort of scuttlebutt and scurrilous nonsense that goes around about politicians at various times. We have seen a bit of that on television this day. At one stage that was particularly intense in Launceston, where I come from, and both Senator Peter Rae and I copped a fair bit of it at various times. He had, as I think most of us but, unfortunately, not all of us have, an abhorrence for that sort of thing. I remember once when stories were being spread about me that he in fact defended me at a meeting of the Liberal Party and made it perfectly clear to people at that meeting that if anyone was going to participate in that he would publicly disown it. Strangely enough, it was not long after that that I had to do the same thing and could reciprocate for him.

It is always difficult in these situations in which a former senator is now a member of the Government in Tasmania and in a party opposed to mine, but I remember with pleasure my time with him in this place. For all our differences, I-as I believe most people did-respected him. I could never understand why, from 1967 until 1983, he was not a Minister in a government in this place, but it is not for me to question what other governments do. I also remember the great fervour with which he defended his State. I remember the fervour with which he defended almost anything that happened in this place. That was something I could not understand, but I also respected the way he played the game. I think that is important, and I am sure he will do the same in the Parliament of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Firstly, I welcome the return of Senator Ruth Coleman to the Senate and wish her good health in the continuance of her contributions, particularly towards the disabled. Secondly, I wish to support the salutatory comments of my colleagues towards former Senator Peter Rae. On Saturday Mr Rae convincingly topped the poll in the electorate of Bass in the Tasmanian State electorate. I think this reflects the very high esteem in which the people of Tasmania hold Peter Rae. Peter Rae was a dedicated worker in all phases of the life of our Senate. His contribution, particularly to the Senate committee system, has been a major factor in raising the public's perception in respect of the Senate and the work of the Senate. Former Senator Rae's other notable achievements include his leadership of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, particularly his work on quangos and raising the status of accountability and public reporting of statutory government organisations. His work on the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange received national recognition. He was a very strong fighter for State rights. He loved his State of Tasmania and defended it on all occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: To his credit, he often took views or supported causes that at times isolated him from the mainstream of his Party and sometimes public opinion. I think this reflects the character of the man. I, therefore, wish to take this opportunity to thank him for his contribution in the Federal arena and wish him a successful career in the Tasmanian State Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The problem with the leaders of the different parties speaking before me is that they steal all the thunder. There seems to me to be very little left to add to what has been said regarding Senator Rae's performance in this place. He was certainly a highly regarded senator for Tasmania. One did not have to ask from which State he came; everybody automatically knew he came from Tasmania. He certainly left his mark on this Senate, particularly in the area of the committee system. As you would be well aware, Mr President, all this has already been said. As Senator Watson said, he topped the poll in the Bass election and this is an indication of the regard in which he is held in his own area. All that remains to me is to wish him well in his new area of politics. I am quite sure that his wife Tessa will be delighted to have him home a lot more than she has been used to. I wish them both well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am slightly different from the rest of my colleagues in as much as I have an association with Peter Rae which goes back 40 years. In 1946, not quite in short pants but all but, I first made Peter's acquaintance. Over those 40 years I followed him, being a few years older, through his early career years. I worked with him on various occasions during his professional career. I think the Parliament is going to be worse off by the standing down of Peter Rae because he did have the interests of the Parliament as his primary objective. He certainly did a considerable amount to see that procedure, dedication to Parliament and knowledge of the Parliament and its systems achieved the top priority. I made a note and I see that I put down `midnight oil'. I am not referring to a music group of any sort but to Peter's working habits. I think that he burnt more midnight oil in this place than anybody else has in the last 20 years.
—I think his officers will have a few lessons coming up very soon.

—I think that may well be. The Tasmanians are going to find that they will work to a different lifestyle from now on. As far as Tasmanians are concerned, there is no doubt that Peter's addition to what was, without him even, a very, very strong team did add to the overall success of his Party in the Tasmanian election on Saturday. I, too, congratulate him on topping the poll in Bass and doing it so well. I am pleased that he will be continuing to serve Tasmania. He can still make an enormous contribution because of the knowledge that he has gained of procedure, of the Parliament and of the ups and downs of the system. I certainly wish him well in the years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to welcome the return of Senator Coleman to the chamber. I have been working on a committee with Senator Coleman for 10 years. Sometimes she has been my boss and sometimes I have been her boss. It has been a very good relationship and I am very pleased to see her back and in the chamber. I hope that she is here for many more years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A lot has been said about Peter Rae. I was particularly interested in what Senator Chipp said about the establishment of friendships in this place. I think that Senator Chipp and Senator Grimes demonstrated that Peter Rae has been able to bridge the gulf between the various parties and has established those friendships in a very real sense. I think Peter Rae came into the Senate in 1968, two years after I went into the House of Representatives, and since that time we have been extremely close friends. I have shared accommodation with him for 12 or 14 years and during that time I have become very conscious of the work load that he has taken upon himself in the interests of the Liberal Party of Australia in the formulation of policies and also with respect to the work of the Senate. Senator Rae, as he was then, has become regarded by the staff and by all senators in all parties as a Senate man who has always defended the role of the Senate, both as a House of review and as a State's house.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp suggested that Peter Rae received some setbacks during his career and it is quite true. He always accepted those setbacks loyally, with his chin out, and always went about his work with renewed vigor in order to promote the interests of the Liberal Party. I think that is an example which many of us in this Parliament could emulate. He attracted remarkable support in the recent State election-I believe something of the order of 22 per cent-second only to the Premier, Robin Gray. That is an indication of the personal following of Peter Rae and the respect with which he is held in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he would make a good Premier?

—I believe that whatever he embarks upon in his new career he will make an excellent job of it. He has always been a man of independent mind and perhaps that is one reason why he attracted such a tremendous vote in Tasmania. I have noted that Tasmanians happen to be fairly independently minded. They do pretty well at elections too. I think Senator Grimes referred to the different view Peter Rae took on the dams issue. That just demonstrates how on this side of the chamber one can responsibly and objectively take a different point of view when, in one's opinion, that view is in the best interests of the State represented. I believe that his interests in resource development, tourism development, economics, legal matters and the abundant knowledge that he takes from the Senate to Tasmania will be of tremendous benefit to that State. There is no doubt in my mind that the Senate's loss is Tasmania's gain.

—Order! I would like to join briefly in welcoming our colleague Senator Coleman back to the Senate after her illness. I took the liberty of writing to her yesterday afternoon expressing a welcome to her on behalf of all honourable senators. I also endorse the remarks that have been made from all political quarters in the chamber concerning our erstwhile colleague Senator Peter Rae. As a result of a long association with me in this Parliament, not only as members of the Senate but also as members of a number of Senate committees, particularly the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee, and having had the pleasure of attending an Inter-Parliamentary Union conference in Bonn with him and his wife we became close personal friends. Not only has he served Tasmania well in this Parliament but he and his wife Tessa-I say this from my own knowledge-were great ambassadors abroad for Australia. I am sure that not only will he be sorely missed in this chamber but also he and his wife in their new role will continue to give great service to the people of Tasmania.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to inform the Senate that staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service met yesterday, 10 February 1986, at 3.00 p.m. to consider their position in relation to demands made by them on 30 October 1985 for a pay increase. The staff resolved to withdraw immediately their services until normal commencement time on the morning of Wednesday, 12 February 1986. The Australian Capital Territory organiser of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union has advised the Joint House Department that this strike will be followed by a series of lightning rolling stoppages in support of the members' claims for a new award which would include satisfactory pay rates and more appropriate conditions of service.

INTERJECT.PARA: The staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service and its union had previously notified the Joint House Department of concern with the classifications and conditions of service applicable under its award. Since October 1985 the union has sought to change the basis of classifications for the catering staff. Discussions have been held between the union and the Joint House Department but a proposal has not been able to be developed that comes within the national wage case guidelines.

The Public Service Board has been informed of the current situation and its advice, and that of officers of the Presiding Officers' advisory group, has been sought in an endeavour to seek a solution. The Joint House Department has proposed discussions between itself, the staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service and the union on 12 February-tomorrow-to seek to achieve withdrawal of the threat of further disruption whilst discussions continue and a basis is developed for the ultimate resolution of the dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to ask a question of you, Mr President, in relation to the dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the requested pay increase within the terms of the accord?
—I have just said that the application to date is outside the wage case guidelines. The negotiations are continuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the hours of meeting for the Senate this day be 2 p.m. till 7.30 p.m.
Mr President, the reasons arise out of the statement that you have just made. I understand that all parties are agreeable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the Senate has been left with no option but to follow this course, but on behalf of the Opposition I register my concern that the sittings of the national Parliament should be disrupted and rearranged because of industrial action. Mr President, on the basis of your statement the people involved in this dispute are no doubt given the biannual wage adjustments provided for under the accord. Supposedly we have an arrangement which will bring about industrial peace in this country and no doubt there is access to arbitral authorities on the basis of any anomalies that may exist. It is quite unsatisfactory that the proceedings of the national Parliament can be disrupted in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I note with particular concern the threat contained in the statement which you read out, Mr President. Of course, that is not a threat from you, but from the people involved that they will conduct a series of lightning stoppages. On behalf of the Opposition I protest in the strongest possible terms. I believe that it is an abuse of the position of the people working here. They should withdraw that threat. If the threat is not withdrawn and if we are subjected to more of this type of action, I believe that it is incumbent on you, Mr President, and the Speaker to make other arrangements to ensure that the Parliament is not disrupted in this way. I am sure that honourable senators and members would accept some external arrangements for food to be made available. Such an outside provision would be quite satisfactory. I am sure members would prefer that to the disruption of the parliamentary sittings. Mr President, I ask you to consider alternative arrangements if we are subjected to any further industrial disruption of this sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the latter part of Senator Chaney's statement. It is intolerable that the meetings of the national Parliament should be dictated to or threatened by a trade union. Even on a matter of principle we ought to find such behaviour totally non-acceptable. Having said that, I do not want it to appear that I am agreeing with the first part of what Senator Chaney said, if he was being critical of the Government's adopting this course of action. I suspect that he was not being critical.
—I said we have to go along with it.

—I understood that the Liberal Party had agreed to this arrangement when the strike action was known about. I commend Senator Grimes for his action because rather than kow-towing to the dictates of a trade union, his only concern was for members of parliament. It seemed to me to be eminently sensible to sit for another hour which means that we will only lose an hour or so of the day and we can finish our business. I commend Senator Grimes for his thoughtfulness to senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am completely unaware of the justification or otherwise of the issue that is causing the dispute. Mr President, you have already said that it is outside the wage guidelines. I take it for granted that that is correct. The fact that the Government is prepared to close down the Parliament because the staff in the dining room decide to go on strike is, I believe, quite reprehensible. The Government really must treat the Parliament more seriously. If anything points to the Government's subservience to the trade unions, this certainly is such an action.

SPEECH.PARA: Are we to rise every time there is a rolling strike next week? Surely government senators can survive for one night on sandwiches, or perhaps they could pop out for a quick counter meal. Do they really have to go to their usual haunts at the Lakeside, Nobbs or wherever to have their long dinners or lunches for which the Government has become so famous? Why can they not fit in with the normal hours? Why can we not rise at 6.30 p.m., go out and have a quick meal and be back at 8 p.m. to sit on? Why should the Parliament rise because some members of the dining room staff decide that they would like to go on strike? The whole matter is quite incredible. I am very opposed to what the Government has suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak to your leader.

—Members on that side of the chamber might be thrown out if they oppose their leader. They should leave the free democracy that we have in this Parliament and country to this side. Those opposite should stick to their leader. They will be thrown out of their party if they do not. We all know that. Members on this side are not thrown out of the party or the Parliament if they disagree. Senator Chaney has already said that the Government has given him no choice but to agree. The Australian Democrats had already agreed; so what rights have we? We on this side can express our opinion.
—Why don't you tell the truth?
—Senator Chipp should decide to come back after eight o'clock. It is ab- solutely reprehensible that the Government--
—Why don't you move an amendment?

—I would very much like to move an amendment. Will Senator Chipp support me if I do? He is being a bit smart. I believe that the Government should change its mind and that we should sit on for the normal sitting hours of the Parliament. If the Government would agree to that, I am sure the two leaders would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Normally I would not exercise my right of reply but, quite frankly, as a result of the stupid contribution that we have just heard, I must. First of all, Senator Walters forgets that there are people in this place other than members of parliament. There are many people in this place other than members of parliament and their situation must also be considered. They also work consistent hours and also eat dinner. Let me tell Senator Walters what happened rather than have put in the Hansard what comes out of her fevered imagination. The arrangement to sit until 7.30 tonight was originally made in the House of Representatives by all parties there. That was where the first arrangement was made.

SPEECH.PARA: We were originally thinking of extending the dinner break by half an hour to make it easier for people to go out to get meals but the other House decided to sit until 7.30 and we thought it fairly sensible to sit for the same hours on this side. I spoke to Senator Chaney before I spoke to Senator Chipp, so Senator Chipp had not agreed to this before Senator Chaney agreed to it. That suggestion came straight out of Senator Walters's well-known imagination. As with so many of the things she says, it was a lie. The simple fact is that there is a dispute. As to whether the dispute is outside of the provisions of the prices and incomes accord, as I am sure it is, this Government's record on union claims outside the accord need not be questioned by Senator Walters. We do not agree to claims outside of the accord and, as it happens, we do not agree with this claim.

We decided that the sensible thing to do was to extend this sitting by an hour and for the House then to rise. This would mean that we would lose one and a half hours. That is the sensible way to cope with this situation and the Opposition side of the Parliament agreed with it. The simple fact is that it is a sensible solution, not only for members of parliament but also for everyone who works in this place. It is a pity that Senator Walters, in her insatiable desire to get headlines on puerile subjects, came in here and made the stupid remarks and attacks that she did. It is an example of how her brain works and of her lack of neurons. I urge honourable senators to support the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION FUND INVESTMENT TRUST AND THE COMMISSIONER FOR SUPERANNUATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Because of its length and very comprehensive nature, I have not had time to analyse in any proper detail the report of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. However, it is interesting to note that it is delivered at a time when the nation is being beseiged by industrial action out in the work place in quest of so-called productivity claims over and above the provisions of the accord in such a way that superannuation is being sought for the work force generally. Whilst the Government has put down some guidelines on how superannuation might be managed when it is introduced, as now seems likely as a result of this industrial action and as a result of the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to be made in respect of the productivity claim before it this week, the Government has not yet made clear how the proposed superannuation arrangements will fit the circumstances of public sector employees. Of course, that is of vast concern to public sector employees, as no doubt it is to their employers.

This report is of some relevance in terms of the immediate situation and immediate industrial events in the community. I for one would like to hear in much more detail from the Government what it proposes in order to take account of the vast involvement of public sector employees in superannuation and how those employees will be advantaged or disadvantaged as a result of the introduction of the new superannuation arrangements. As we know, employees in the public sector will receive the 3 per cent benefit if indeed the Arbitration Commission makes such a decision, as is expected.

Turning to the report, it is interesting to note that the Government is now spending a total of some $900m a year on pensions and lump sum benefits to former employees of the Commonwealth. That includes employees of such statutory authorities as the Australian Postal Commission, the Australian Telecommunications Commission and other such bodies. I hasten to point out that that amount of some $900m does include refunds of individual employee contributions which total some $109m, or roughly one-ninth of the total payouts. Thus, the contributions made by employees appear to represent only one-ninth of the total benefit that the pensioners receive. Of course, this needs some qualification because it is interesting to note that, of the total expenditure of some $901m, roughly $535m comes by way of contribution from the various statutory authorities of the Commonwealth. I am not sure from the accounting in the report whether the employee component of contributions to the superannuation fund is nominated under that heading or in the earlier part of the report under employer components. Therefore, it is a little difficult to analyse.

The point that is of some interest and significance is that the average pension payable in the last financial year was $10,452, which is one-half, or a little less, of average weekly earnings. That compares with the Department of Social Security age pension which represents a little under 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. Thus, there is indeed a very significant benefit in favour of public sector employees. The other point of significance is that statistics show that the annual pensioner liability at the end of June 1985 was $761.6m. I suppose that, if we take into account the average life expectancy of a retiree, that means that the total liability of the superannuation scheme could be about $12,000m. It is a significant liability to the Commonwealth and one that will demand some interest and certainly supervision by this Parliament as years go by.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The debates on education continue in this chamber and we debate the education reports as they come up. This report gives us a chance to look once again at the whole approach of the Australian Labor Party and the Labor Government to education, and to raise once again for the Australian public the way in which Labor seeks to downgrade choice, to limit access to higher education and to endanger excellence in education. This report quite properly identifies the Government's goals, and quite properly identifies departmental goals in line with the Government's goals, and quite properly identifies the Department of Education as an organ of government. I have no objection to that, and what I say contains no criticism of the Department of Education because it is there to put into effect what the government of the day seeks by way of policy. But the Department at page 1 of its report identifies its objectives. That exercise is of course one which I always applaud but it identifies as one of its objectives:
To relate policies in Australian education to the Government's social, cultural, economic and foreign policies.

In other words, as the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has said many times, if the Government has its way education in Australia will advance the Government's goals for various aspects of Australian life. The concern of the Opposition is that these goals are bad goals, that the Government has little feeling for the need for excellence in education. The Minister for Education has said that the search for excellence has, to use her words, `overtones of elitism'. We reject that. We believe that excellence in education in Australia, and the pursuit of excellence, is absolutely critical to the achievement of our national goals. We believe that the Government has got it wrong in seeking to downgrade excellence in any way. We are concerned about the Government's system of education, which ends up restricting access. We will turn away this year from higher education in New South Wales 30,000 potential students who seek to do nothing more than improve themselves; to add to the pool of skills available to Australia; who seek to improve their own life chances by increasing the number of options which they have available. They will be refused access because of the policies of the Government and the restricted number of places available. If the Department is required to pursue goals which have that kind of effect, they too are bad goals.

The Government has other goals. We can go back to the Minister's speeches over the years. She is not so concerned, as we are, with equality of opportunity for Australians, but she is concerned to seek equality in the outcomes of education. Equality of outcomes almost inevitably means that she is rejecting the idea of equality of opportunity. We have diametrically opposed views. Her pursuit of equality of outcomes will be bad for Australian education. She wonders why parents continue in their droves to vote with their feet and take their children to schools where excellence is admired and sought, where choice is valued, where discipline is part of the offering, where a view of life which values achievement is offered and where equality of outcomes is seen as the empty and wanting goal that it really is. I find this report quite acceptable in terms of the record that it gives of what the Department of Education has done but in the sense that it is a testament to the Government's policies it continues to disappoint Australian parents and to disappoint Australian educational aspirations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHERRIES IN BRINE OR OTHER PRESERVATIVEBIOLOGICAL CONTROL OF ECHIUM SPECIESPASSENGER CONCESSIONSTHE HEAVY ENGINEERING INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The only comment I wish to make at this stage relates to the Industries Assistance Commission report on passenger concessions. It is interesting to see that this report, which has now been tabled, is dated 6 November 1985 and predates by some weeks the debate in the Senate on the Government's legislation on passenger concessions. Honourable senators will recall that the Opposition opposed the Government's inward duty free shopping proposals and did so on the basis of its concern at the possible reduction of barrier control, or the complication of barrier control which the introduction of inward duty free shopping would present.

Under the Government's new arrangements there are to be shopping points between the point of exit from an aircraft and the Customs barrier. Whilst on the face of it that might seem a useful additional facility for incoming passengers it also presents an additional difficulty for those who are trying to control the flow of people and of possible illicit goods through the Customs barrier. It means that additional people will be introduced into the movement across the barrier. The report confirms that there is concern that the proposals would hinder Customs operations. It states:
Indeed, the probability is that, in some airports, it would hinder Customs in processing passengers and achieving the other objectives of barrier control.

The principal concern is that there should not be any further complication of the very real difficulties that Customs faces in controlling the flow of drugs into this country. I just wanted on this occasion to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the final report, like the interim report we had before us at the time we debated the legislation, brings out this same problem. It is a matter which is of continuing concern to the Opposition and a matter which we would want to follow up further in the light of experience following these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some remarks on the Industries Assistance Commission report on the biological control of echium species, including Paterson's curse or Salvation Jane. I am glad that the report has recommended the biological control of echium, and of course Salvation Jane or Paterson's curse is a part of that family. This weed has created great problems for rural communities in New South Wales and many other parts of Australia. After each of the droughts we have had in the past there has been an increase in Paterson's curse caused by the deterioration of improved pastures. Of course Paterson's curse, or Salvation Jane, has caused great problems as a result of the death of stock as a result of kidney failure, and of course anyone who runs a property does not like to see his stock dying in this way. This weed has the name of Salvation Jane because, eaten by stock in small proportions, it has had a lifesaving effect on stock in the far west of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons that the recommendations in the report were not introduced earlier is that apiarists would have some cause for complaint if Paterson's curse were eradicated because it plays quite a part in the production of honey. However, the report covers the worries of apiarists by saying that if biological control affects such groups it may be to an extent that it warrants adjustment assistance, although uncertainties still exist as to whether that would be effective. It is suggested that any assistance not be given until the effects of the biological control are fully investigated. This is something that members of the rural community will welcome as they are under threat at the moment from this centralised socialist Hawke Labor Government. They will welcome this report because it will help them to save some money. According to the report, something like $115m in current dollar terms will be saved over 15 years by the rural communities. The cost to the beekeeping industry will be some $8m in discounted terms over 15 years. I hope that this report will now mean the end of any opposition to the biological control of this weed because it has had a far reaching effect throughout rural communities for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a few remarks to the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on passenger concessions. Legislation for inward duty free shopping was introduced into this place and forced through as a result of a shoddy little deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats, despite the fact that it was massively opposed by the Australian Customs Service, which not only has responsibility now for the monitoring of inward duty free shopping but also was alert to the security risks and other dangers which would be a consequence of the introduction of inward duty free shopping. The Government similarly refused to allow the Senate to have any form of inquiry into the problems for Customs at the barrier that would be associated with the introduction of inward duty free shopping. It is interesting to note that the Industries Assistance Commission has investigated this matter over a number of years. It has been the subject of considerable discussion by the Bureau of Transport Economics and by various interdepartmental committees, all of which, on the basis of their expert advice, have recommended against inward duty free shopping.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at page 84 of the report one is drawn to the question of passenger and aircraft safety. It was argued as a great point by Senator Sanders that somehow inward duty free shopping would enhance passenger and flight safety. That is totally untrue. The IAC nails that assertion by saying:

In its 1979 study, the Bureau of Transport Economics was sceptical of the safety claims made. It had not found any evidence of accidents having been exacerbated by duty free goods being carried on an aircraft . . . The fire risk from passengers' alcohol was considered to be no greater than that from the airlines' own stocks of liquor . . . Even if duty free goods, carried as cabin baggage, were a serious safety risk, inward duty free shopping would not solve the problem unless carriage of all duty free goods in the cabin of the aircraft were banned.

The Government, of course, does not propose to do that. The report indicates the additional costs to the Customs Service of the introduction of inward duty free shopping. It draws attention to the fact that the Customs Service and the Department of Immigration have specifically disagreed with the claim that inward duty free shopping would facilitate passenger movement through the barrier and the Customs terminals. It draws attention to the difficulties that will be encountered with the necessity from time to time for the alteration of passenger Customs declarations. On page 87 the report goes on to indicate:
There is also doubt whether inward duty free shopping could be restricted to airports.

Undoubtedly, we will now see the expansion of this area and a consequent loss of revenue to the Government. The rationale for the export of goods through duty free shops is criticised by the report as a violation of the destination principle of indirect taxation. The concluding paragraph of this section of the report, paragraph 7.4.4, states:

The reference requires the Commission to comment on the applicability of recommended concessions to goods purchased in Australia by arriving persons before they pass through the Customs barrier. The objectives of passenger concessions are passenger facilitation, immigration, and cost-effectiveness in Customs administration. The Commission does not believe that inward duty free shopping helps to achieve any of these objectives. Indeed, the probability is that, in some airports, it would hinder Customs in processing passengers and achieving the other objectives of barrier control. The Commission therefore considers that passenger import concessions should not apply to goods purchased in Australia by arriving persons before they pass through the Customs barrier.

The Government has decided, for what I think are quite improper and shoddy reasons, to reject the recommendations of the IAC. I believe that the Government will wear the responsibility for the loss of revenue and increased difficulty for the airlines and the Customs Service. It will wear the responsibility for the additional opportunity which is provided for smuggling and the entry of narcotics into this country by the use of the inward duty free system, which I discussed at length last year in my speech on the Customs legislation which introduced it. I believe it will be found that the very shoddy and underhand deal which the Government entered into and which was promoted by certain sections of the Government to the detriment of revenue and the Customs Service will be a lasting blot on the Government's record in this area and is a clear indication of how little attention the Government is prepared to give to the expert and considered recommendations of the IAC in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission in its report entitled `Biological Control of Echium Species'. The Industries Assistance Commission was commissioned to report on the biological effects of Paterson's curse being a target species under an Act recently passed by this Parliament. I support the recommendation that the species be a target species and should be managed by Government agencies supported by public funding. The Commission acknowledges that Paterson's curse can impinge on the natural environment through its presence in national parks and other conservation areas which are set aside in order to protect the native vegetation. I do not believe that point was adequately made in the debate on biological control. I commend the Commission for bringing the matter to our attention. The report also acknowledges that Paterson's curse impinges on soil erosion, with detrimental effects on both agricultural and public land. The native vegetation is also affected as a result of chemical spraying to control Paterson's curse.

SPEECH.PARA: Biological control is a very effective and cheap means of controlling agricultural problems in Australia. The vast scale of our agriculture, the limited numbers of people and the high costs of cultivation and imported sprays mean that biological control is a very effective means of reducing farm costs, eliminating pests and improving pasture species and animal nutrition. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985 makes a number of very important changes to the Trade Practices Act. In the course of that it also adds considerably to the impact of that legislation and to the powers of the Minister who is administering that legislation from time to time. The Trade Practices Act was first passed by this Parliament basically in its present form in 1974, which is less than 12 years ago. Of course, that Act and the many subsequent amendments to it, together with the great volume of case law which has emerged in relation to it, are a very salutary example of the great regulation of conduct promoted by this Parliament on far too many occasions. The Opposition has supported the essential principle of the Trade Practices Act; that is, that, in essence, it is pro-competitive regulation. But, unfortunately, as soon as parliaments and governments become involved in legislation of this or any other kind which is adding to regulation, they build one block on another over a period of years and we end up with the state of affairs from which this nation is suffering at present due to the activities of parliament and governments over the last two decades or more in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: Although, as I have said, in essence and in principle the Opposition supports pro-competitive regulation of the kind in the Trade Practices Act, it approaches legislation of this kind, amendments to it and extensions of it with a very critical eye. It is our view that this example of proposed legislation should be opposed because we do not see that the benefits that may flow from this Bill justify the increased burdens of regulation in one form or another which it will impose, particularly those very considerable extensions of ministerial power which are included in this legislation under the proposed product safety additions to the Trade Practices Act. There may be the odd benefit in this legislation, the odd clause which, if it were standing on its own, we would not be fazed about. But, on the whole, we see this piece of legislation as one which should not have been introduced into this Parliament in its present form. We certainly would want to amend it extensively but, in essence, we are opposed to it and will be voting against the second reading of it for those reasons.

If the Bill is read a second time, contrary to our opinion, we propose to move that the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs because it is a Bill which requires the close attention of the Parliament, particularly the Senate as the House of Review, before it becomes law. It requires much greater attention to detail than we would be able to give to it in the Committee of the Whole. We do not think that form of procedure is desirable. For one thing, a great many representations have been made by a large number of most important organisations in relation to this legislation. Their representations have been very detailed and very thoughtful and they deserve to be very closely examined and examined in a way that is not possible in the Committee of the Whole of this chamber. I will say more about that if we reach the stage where the Bill proceeds, which I think is likely from what I understand to be the views of the Australian Democrats, and I will not anticipate what Senator Haines will say when she follows me in this debate. I understand that the Bill will probably be passed by the Senate despite our opposition to it. I can develop that argument at a later stage.

Finally, if that move fails and the legislation is examined, albeit in an unsatisfactory way, by this chamber in Committee, the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments to the legislation, the details of which unfortunately have not yet been printed, unless one of the Clerks at the table has them, but I hope that they will be circulated as soon as possible. I hope that other amendments will be circulated as soon as possible. The Government is now circulating amendments which it proposes to move. This is the Government's second bite at the cherry with this legislation, despite the fact that it brought this legislation down some 2 1/2 years after it was first elected with proposals to amend the Trade Practices Act. Having introduced this Bill in the House of Representatives, the Government added to it by bringing in some amendments on the very day it was being debated in the House of Representatives without any proper consideration being able to be given to those amendments, and they were passed in the House of Representatives. At the end of last week, on the eve of the debate here this week, the Government proposed further amendments, and I understand that there will be amendments from the Australian Democrats. That indicates the sort of problem that this Parliament, in particular the Senate, has in dealing with legislation of a very technical kind with the very detailed form of regulation which I have already complained about. We are proceeding in this way to add further to the burdens of regulation on the business community and no doubt on the community generally, but this legislation is of course aimed particularly at adding to the burdens of business.

I would like to examine just what the Government's policies are in relation to this matter. I have already mentioned the very great increase that has occurred in the burden of regulation over the last two decades. My colleague Mr Spender referred in another place to some very alarming statistics, namely, that through the 1960s and the 1970s this Federal Parliament passed about 17,000 new Acts or amendments to other Acts and in that same period governments promoted 32,000 new or additional statutory rules. It is really a most incredible record that, in the space of 20 years, that sort of absolutely mindless parliamentary activity has added more and more to legislative burdens. That has been a role of this Parliament under successive governments, and the situation has now reached the stage where the community, the business community in particular, is simply groaning under that sort of burden.

The Opposition, and indeed the Government, are giving consideration to this problem. The Government's rhetoric on this would seem to indicate that it takes the same attitude to this additional piece of legislation as the Opposition is taking. In November 1984, just before the 1984 election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that unnecessary institutional and legal impediments needed to be removed from this country's productive sources. In July last year the Government set up a body known as the review of business regulations. We had further noises from the Prime Minister last year about how he understood the complaints of the business world and how the Government was going to do something about it. Yet at the same time as this rhetoric is being pursued by the Government we have legislation of this kind which is going to add greatly to the burdens of regulations on this community.

Of course, the Government's concern about regulation of the business community is not being extended to the power and influence that the union movement has and its effect on the business community. One of the centrepieces of the Government's policy, indeed one of the major features of the Green Paper that it issued a year or two ago on amendments to the Trade Practices Act, was a commitment to remove one of the few but most effective means of containing trade union power in this country, namely, section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. An indication of the Government's attitude in this matter, although the Government's proposals for amendments generally to the Trade Practices Act were deferred until now, is that the Government brought forward last year a Bill to remove section 45d which is one of the most effective tools with which business can cope with union power. Although in this legislation and in many other pieces of legislation the Government, despite its rhetoric, is proposing further regulations and regulatory burdens on the business community, on the commercial life of this country, it is not proposing any similar curbs on union power. In essence, a great deal of union power is directed towards reducing competition in the commercial world to protect the interests of union members. The Government wanted to remove one way of controlling that in the shape of section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. We are confronted with enormous power exercised by a major union like the Builders Labourers Federation in relation to which the Government still has not really achieved any of its purposes, in that there are bans on people in the building industry who cannot get on with their business because of the exercise of union power of that kind. The Transport Workers Union is another good example. We have an example of the activities of that union today throughout Australia in its virtually bringing to a halt major airline services.

I have also had my attention drawn to the fact that in the Australian Capital Territory in recent years there has been a reduction of 50 per cent in the number of people allowed by the Transport Workers Union to operate what are called agitator trucks or concrete mixers. The numbers of people able to engage in that business in this Territory, under our very eyes, have been reduced by half simply because of the bans by the BLF and the TWU on the entry of those who are allowed by the unions to engage in proper, commercial and competitive activity. What is the Government doing about all these things? It is doing absolutely nothing. This Government is interested only in adding to the burdens of business. It will do nothing to remove the burdens on competitive commercial activity in this country imposed by powerful trade unions, which are its friends and supporters, particularly I suppose its financial supporters.

To come back to the Government's view on business regulations, I mentioned earlier that it set up a business regulation review unit. That provided a first report, called an information paper, in January, less than a month ago. This is a very interesting document because it provides the sort of information which the business community has been saying should be considered and understood and which members of the public, even members of parliament, have not understood. This review committee is doing a very good job. I hope that the Government is going to take notice of the committee which it has set up but, to judge from its past performance, I do not think there is much likelihood of that occurring. This committee has identified that 16,400 Commonwealth personnel are engaged in or supporting those engaged in business regulatory activities under one of many possible definitions. That is simply Commonwealth officialdom. It does not deal with all the enormous regulation by States or the large number of other types of staff engaged in Federal regulatory activities which do not come under the definition of `directly engaged'. The business regulation review unit lists them.

The review unit makes another startling conclusion; that is, if one includes all the staff who are engaged-but not solely and directly engaged-in the regulation of business the figure of 16,400 would double. If we went 50-50 or something like that, at least 20,000 positions could be saved by a reduction in this regulatory burden. The cost of the 16,400 officers is in excess of $700m per annum. If one adds to that figure the cost of the other positions, one sees that well over $1 billion is paid by the Commonwealth Government alone for this regulatory burden.

Today Senator Evans said: This Government cannot possible afford to give ordinary Australian people-motorists, farmers and everybody else-a reduction in the cost of petrol because the Government would lose something like $1 billion today. That is one way the Government could find major reductions in expenditure and give people what they are entitled to and what is due to them under the Government's policies which it has been running for three years. I implore the Government and the Senate to have regard to exactly where we are today in the regulation of business and the burden on business. The business regulation review unit gives only the costs and burdens of regulation on business, much less all the other regulations of other aspects of people's lives.

This legislation is particularly offensive to us because of the extension of the Minister's role under the Trade Practices Commission in relation to product safety or the consumer affairs section-Part V of the Trade Practices Act. The real problem of this area is not only the ministerial power that it contains. If this legislation is passed we will propose amendments which will try to improve it. One of the really worrying things about this legislation is the duplication of Commonwealth and State regulation. We have this whole crushing burden of regulation which I have mentioned over the last two or three decades. That has been going on in State parliaments and State governments. Consumer protection has been a major feature of State parliaments and governments. I think Ministers responsible for consumer affairs all have consumer protection bodies of one sort or another. State governments are far better suited to administering this sort of government activity.

However, if it were felt by the Australian nation that it wanted regulation at a Federal level-I would not like to see that-there is certainly some case for uniform legislation. The efforts that have been made over the years by State Ministers meeting with the Federal Minister from time to time have been directed at getting uniformity of legislation. That is a desirable course. What is thoroughly undesirable is the fact that one has the whole burden of State legislation and the whole burden of Federal legislation on top of it which deals with the same area. We have two bureaucracies. In every State around Australia we have probably eight or nine bureaucracies which have all been developed to deal with these matters. Thus the sort of burden which is finally identified by the report of the business regulation review unit which I have mentioned is now compounded over and over again by the duplication of government activities in Australia, federally and State-wide.

I have said that the Opposition supports the principle of the Trade Practices Act but it has never supported the increasing role of the Commonwealth Government in the consumer protection area-which is referred to in Part V of the Trade Practices Act-because of the duplication of activity. This legislation is not only another example of duplication; it also duplicates an area where there has been a great deal of self- regulation by industry. The product safety and product recall schemes have been developed by industry as part of its self-regulation. We believe that that is the best way to go. Of course it is supplemented by ordinary common law rules and developments in common law.

Another example in this legislation is the introduction of the right of remedy in the case of what are called unconscionable contracts. No doubt we will debate that in some detail later. However new forms of remedy-admittedly there is some precedent for it in some States-are being introduced at the Federal level in areas which are traditionally matters of common law or State law. I do not believe that we in the Federal Parliament should add to the development. Some remarkable developments occur in the common law system in relation to contract law. In recent years the High Court of Australia has been most innovative in this sphere and I have no doubt that in due course it will develop very satisfactory rules, far more satisfactory rules than we will develop by this approach of detailed legislation which is not understood and which has not even been properly debated in this Parliament. The House of Representatives did not have time to debate it. It was guillotined there. Fortunately the Senate has time to debate it but we also have countless other matters of concern to debate. It is not the sort of debate that we can usefully have in this Parliament. This is absolutely the wrong way of going about providing remedies which may be necessary-probably in most cases they are not necessary.

As I said earlier, it is for those reasons that the Opposition will oppose this legislation at the second reading stage. We believe that the Government is going about this process in the wrong way. There are better ways of doing it. We are simply adding to the existing regulations. We can imagine how much litigation will arise for a start if we pass legislation providing new remedies for unconscionable contracts. Our efforts would simply stir up more activity. It would be an absolute bonanza for the legal profession. We have heard constant complaints, particularly from the Australian Democrats, about the legal profession, the inadequacies of people having rights, legal aid and all the rest of it. Yet here we are-presumably we have the support of the Democrats-adding greatly to the fortunes of the legal profession. I believe it is totally hypocritical to be complaining about lawyers, as I hear often in this chamber, when, at the same time, people in this chamber are constantly adding to the problems of ordinary people, particularly, in the case of this legislation, to the problems of businessmen, and they can cope with those problems only by seeking legal advice and taking legal action. Courts will be further and further clogged up. That is to say nothing of the fact that the taxpayer is groaning under the burden of more than $1 billion a year which was identified by the business regulation review unit of this Government only a few weeks ago. No doubt that is only the tip of the iceberg, because it does not cover what the States are doing; it does not cover the costs of all this regulation on business itself. For those reasons the Opposition will be opposing the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by saying that I have considerable doubts that this piece of legislation will cause a lawyer-led recovery of the sort that Senator Durack indicated it would, mainly through the section on unconscionable conduct. For what it is worth, I refer him to the United States uniform commercial code, which is similar in intention and does not seem to have caused that problem in any untoward manner over there. Certainly Senator Durack is right in his discussion of the scope of this legislation, but I would challenge his assertion that it is a bad piece of legislation because it is unnecessarily extending regulations. It certainly affects everything from mergers to mandatory recall, but it does so as a consequence of the fact that it has been about nine years since the Trade Practices Act was in any way significantly amended, and that was done as a result of the last major review, or at least the one prior to this Government's Green Paper, which was undertaken by the Swanson Committee in 1976 and produced amendments in 1977, nine years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Since then many things have happened. Apart from deficiencies revealed by the experience gained by the Trade Practices Commission and by judicial decisions, some of which are narrow in the extreme, major changes have taken place in Australian industry, and there is a greater trend towards increased concentration. For those people who are either not aware of this or do not feel particularly uneasy about it, I would direct them, for a start, to the behaviour of the Bell Group towards Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in recent weeks. As a consequence of these sorts of changes, as a consequence of the fact that it is some nine years since the Swanson Committee's recommendations were taken up, and, I might add, following considerable consultation with relevant business and consumer organisations, the Government's Green Paper on proposals for change was issued, almost exactly two years ago, and this, too, has been discussed at considerable length, to say nothing of depth, within the community.

As a consequence, we have a piece of legislation before us in which there are significant amendments aimed at improving the effectiveness of restrictive trade practice provisions and extending the protection afforded to consumers by the Act. I would point out, too, that consumers are not necessarily just individual people. There is an increasing number of small business operations which would classify themselves as consumers and which have been increasingly concerned over recent years that they are not being sufficiently covered by the Act.

The major proposals that this Bill approaches are those concerned with the misuse of market power, the unconscionable conduct about which Senator Durack was so anxious, product recall, and measures enabling the Trade Practices Commission to seek compensation for named defrauded persons. Generally speaking, and contrary to what Senator Durack has said in part in his speech, I suggest that the amendments represent a realistic and balanced approach to much needed reforms. That is not to say that the Bill has not been without its critics. Indeed, the Law Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, the Australian Council of Soft Drink Manufacturers, and the Senate's beloved Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills have all raised concerns about various clauses of the Bill. Consumer organisations have also put in their two cents worth.

As I said a moment ago, the main contentious clauses, those which have been commented on by an assortment of organisations, including the Law Council of Australia and some of the organisations that represent big business as distinct from those organisations that represent small business, include the misuse of market power, the unconscionable conduct section, the mandatory product recall clauses, the section relating to mergers and other acquisitions, and the section relating to misleading statements. But there are other less contentious but no less important elements of this piece of legislation that deserve to be looked at. Those include the sections relating to section 4B, which, for example, acknowledge the fact that inflation has occurred over recent years and has eroded the monetary limit of $15,000 currently in section 4B, so that that, under the Bill, has been increased to $40,000. To the best of my knowledge no one is complaining about that fact and, indeed, small business organisations believe that it gives them even greater protection.

In addition to that, a specific protection is provided for truck owner-operators following the recommendation in the national road freight industry inquiry. Whilst the Law Council of Australia, probably with some justification, questions the inclusion of one particular group in this piece of legislation, we believe that, under the conditions that I have mentioned-namely, that it follows the recommendation from the national road freight industry inquiry-it is justified. In addition, we have changes to section 58 relating to a corporation accepting payment without intending or being able to supply goods, and the amendments to sections 64 and 65 relating to fraudulent claims for unsolicited advertising or entries in a directory. Anyone who has read the complaints that have come, particularly from small business, in these areas, as expressed in newspapers in recent months, will realise that this problem seems to be a growing one. This Bill is an attempt, in part, to provide protection. Certainly the legislation is not perfect, but I would suggest that if we sat around in this place waiting for any government to produce a perfect piece of legislation we would be here until doomsday and even less would get done than normally gets done.

The legislation has, however, been significantly improved by the Government already in its acceding to certain amendments suggested by the Law Council of Australia and in discussions over the last few months with the Australian Democrats as well. I believe that it can be further improved, particularly in relation to the protection that it gives to small business. We shall be picking up a number of amendments left over from the suggestions from the Law Council of Australia and the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia.

I cannot see that there is any real need to send this piece of legislation to a committee, for a number of reasons. First of all, I find it difficult to come up with any Senate standing committee that is, in fact, an appropriate body to which to send a piece of legislation such as this. As I said at the beginning, it covers everything from mergers to mandatory recall, and even the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would take some time to come to terms with all of that. There certainly are not enough senators left in this place to form a select committee to which to send this legislation. Furthermore, apart from concerns expressed by big business, it is essentially a piece of good consumer legislation under which consumers, whether they are individuals or small businesses, will get more protection than they do currently. In broad terms, I suggest that the Bill does provide significant additional protection for individual consumers and small business. Given the rhetoric that we are accustomed to hearing from the Opposition parties about their concern for small business, I would have thought that one of their primary concerns would be that this Bill does in fact provide additional protection for what they seem to regard, if one listens to the rhetoric, as part of their natural constituency.

I have already covered things like the section 4b amendment. The section 46 amendments strengthen the hand of the Trade Practices Commission is dealing with complaints by small businesses against powerful firms. That was certainly a concern that the small business people expressed to us. They have felt increasingly out in the cold when it has come to support from the Government under this legislation. The amendment to section 53 to prohibit misleading representations about the availability of spare parts or repair facilities will assist farmers, for example. Again, I would have thought that that was a concern that the Opposition shared with us. I have already mentioned concern about sections 65 and 64 when it comes to fraudulent claims for payment. The Bill, however, is not, as Senator Durack seemed to imply, anti-business in the sense that it imposes excessive regulations or requirements on big business. Part IV is aimed at freeing up markets and the amendments do not depart from that policy. The section 46 amendments will continue to protect businesses entering new markets or expanding existing markets from firms that abuse their market power. In short, the amended Trade Practices Act would prohibit unscrupulous conduct and encourage aggressive and fair but competitive conduct from reputable businesses.

A letter that I have from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia has almost nothing but praise for the legislation. Where it differs with the Bill is a complaint that the recommendations for amendment to section 49 made in the Green Paper have not been picked up by the Government.
