I have no real idea why the Government has not except that it may be that it agrees with the Law Council of Australia in its suggestion that the amendments currently being made to section 46 offer small business the same sort of protection that groups like COSBOA feel would come from strengthening section 49. Notwithstanding that fact, however, we believe that it is appropriate to continue along the lines that the small business organisations would like to see and as a consequence we will be moving an amendment to section 49 along the lines of that suggested and recommended in the Green Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —With Liberal support.

—Senator Chipp interjects that we would expect Liberal support. I certainly hope that we get it. I am not sure that I am going to hold my breath waiting, given the remarks that Senator Durack made earlier which seemed to indicate that the Liberals are yet again trading off the interests of small business for that of big business in this country. The amendment suggested in the Green Paper to section 49 would allow the average small business some change of taking action against those businesses which use unfair and commercially unjustifiable price discrimination to erode the small business share of the market. For example, larger discounts are given to a chain of grocers or a multi-branch business with large buying power than are given to small organisations. As I said, the Law Council believes that this sort of protection is adequately covered in the proposed amendments to section 46 but, certainly, beleaguered small business people, such as those represented by COSBOA, would feel more comfortable and secure with the extra protection afforded by this change to section 49, and we will be proceeding with that. The letter that I referred to a moment ago from the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia was in fact addressed to Senator Chipp and it reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: When you addressed us earlier this year you assured us that your Party was in favour of providing adequate protection for small business, from unfair competition, through amendment of the Trade Practices Act.

As you know, the Government has proposed a range of amendments most of which we agree with, and we concede that the amendment of Section 46 may be of some assistance to small business in some special circumstances.

However, the fundamental need for protection of small business is a strengthening of Section 49, Price Discrimination, as this is an area which on prima facie evidence is widely exploited by large interests to vary the market situation at the expense of small firms, which are in practice unable to make use of Section 49, despite its underlying intent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why the Liberal Party won't support us.

—The Liberal Party, I am sure, has, as indeed you did, Senator Chipp, assured people like COSBOA that it is interested in providing adequate protection for small business. We will see whether it intends to follow that statement with any sort of action. It is important to these people that they feel that they are covered, particularly since, as they point out in the letter, there has been only one successful case under section 49 in the history of the Act and that had some special features attaching to it. The fact that there have been no others indicates just how unusable the present legislation is, at least as far as COSBOA is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: We will be looking too at a number of issues that were raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in particular clause 20 relating to interpretation. This clause relates to a corporation making representations when it does not have reasonable grounds for doing so. It is the intention of this amendment to define representations as misleading if the grounds for making them were not reasonable. The Law Council of Australia and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have both expressed concerns in this area. The particular concern raised here is about the reversal of the onus of proof in sub-clause (2). After raising the matter with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and receiving his response, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had this to say:

The Committee thanks the Attorney-General for his response and in particular for the clear statement of Commonwealth policy on the reversal of the persuasive onus of proof. However, while the Committee is prepared to concede that in some instances the reversal of the persuasive onus of proof may be justified by the particular circumstances of the case-
the Committee refers back to comments the Committee made in its sixteenth report-

the Committee does not believe that this is such a case. In most criminal proceedings the prosecution is required to prove the state of mind of the accused and it is difficult to see why belief as to the correctness of promises or predictions should be in any different position. The Committee suggests that in this case a reasonable balance would be struck by placing on the defendant an evidential burden, since the basis upon which it makes its predictions is peculiarly within its knowledge, but then requiring the prosecution to rebut the evidence so advanced.
Having said that, the Committee went on to say that it:

. . . continues to draw the clause to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) in that by imposing the persuasive onus of proof on the defendant it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

We will be picking up that particular comment from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, echoed by the Law Council of Australia, and we will move an amendment in line with what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has suggested.

There has been a suggestion that some of the narrower interpretations of some sections of the Trade Practices Act could be avoided if the Government were a little more consistent in its wording. Concerning clause 20 of the Bill, in sub-clause (3) the words `shall not be taken' should in fact read `shall be deemed not' and so on. Honourable senators who have a copy of the Bill will realise that this will change the words `shall not be taken to limit by implication the meaning of a reference in this Division' to `shall be deemed not to limit by implication'. As I started to say a moment ago, this may seem to be nitpicking, but one has only to look at some extraordinary narrow interpretations of sections of the Trade Practices Act in some courts to realise that judges sometimes need all the help they can get. This amendment will go some way to providing that help. The Democrats will move what is essentially a minor drafting amendment but which could pre-empt some of the more narrow interpretations that have arisen in the past.

I turn now to the `unconscionable conduct' provision in clause 21. Groups such as the Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association, the Small Business Association of Australia and others believe that it does not go far enough in the sense that protection under the clause does not cover them. They want it extended to cover all dealings. Our amendment will relate to sub-sections (5) and (6) so that they include consumers such as members of APADA in the scope of the legislation. We would also like to see the word `consumer', wherever it occurs in that clause, replaced with the word `person'.

In addition, the insertion of the proposed new section 52 which deals with conflict of interest would require people having any beneficial interest in the commercial transaction involved to declare that interest. Again, that is of some interest to farmers, for example, who regularly sell through agents. Finally, I turn to clause 34 about which, again, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has expressed some concern at the lack of parliamentary scrutiny or review of sections 65C and 65F. On page 39 of its seventeenth report, the Committee states:
Clause 35 inserts a new Division 1A in Part V of the Act dealing with product safety matters.
It continues:

Notices under sub-sections 65c (5) and (7) are not required to be tabled in Parliament and are not subject to disallowance. There is no effective form of review by an independent, quasi-judicial tribunal of the Minister's decisions to declare goods unsafe or to ban them. The only avenue of review afforded is that, under new section 65j, a draft of a notice under either sub-section must be prepared and suppliers of the goods in question invited by notice in the Gazette to request a conference with the Commission.

The Government's own amendments do something to satisfy concerns expressed by, for example, the Law Council of Australia, in that they have extended the notification process to include contracting and writing as far as possible for supplies of the goods. This does not solve the problem expressed specifically of a non-reviewable decision by a Minister. It is suggested that there should be some reference to bodies such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and they reiterate their concern about this matter with a similar concern expressed about clause 65f. Again, we will take that matter up in an amendment provided that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee at its meeting tomorrow morning at half past eight does not reconsider its concern in the light of any response from the Attorney-General.

I repeat that as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned we believe that, with some additional amendments, the Bill before us will significantly improve the manner in which the Trade Practices Act protects consumers. I include in that term small businesses of the kind that form the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia and the Small Business Association. To that end, this is public spirited legislation which is pro-competition and is not anti-business, but operates in the interests of the business community and individual consumers across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a lot of courage for Senator Haines or anyone else to say that the addition of another major burden on the business community is in its own interests. I commend her for her courage but certainly not for her foresight. As Senator Durack has already pointed out, a cost of something like $1 billion a year is already the burden of regulations on business. Cost must always be related to benefit. When one considers the benefits in this new set of amendments compared with their cost, not only the direct cost in terms of additional regulation of the business community and small business but also the cost in terms of damage in many instances to the competitive process, the reduction of prices and damage to the more effective operating of the market place by intervention, we recognise that the costs in this case appear to far outweigh the benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt in my mind that while we have to recognise the need for protection of small businesses, as Senator Haines mentioned, from unfair competition we have to make certain that the measures taken to do so do not have other consequential effects which will be more damaging to individual freedoms, to small businesses and to the efficient operation of our society and our economy than would take place otherwise. It seems to me that this collection of amendments to the trade practices legislation which Senator Haines regards as a well-balanced approach to much needed reforms has already demonstrated that it is not anything like as good as it is cracked up to be.

Already the Government has been obliged to make major changes. In fact, these changes took place after the Bill had been through the House of Representatives. It is simply another case of the Government endeavouring to get through legislation even though it is evidently and demonstrably inappropriate, certainly as far as those people most affected by it are concerned. The fact that it was pushed through the House of Representatives before further amendments were made by the Government-we received some on our desks about three minutes ago-indicates a lack of proper consultation, particularly when we recognise that the Government at one stage was seeking to ram it through this place in December. I am overjoyed that the Opposition was not prepared to be a party to that.

Apart from adding to the enormous cost of regulation of business and therefore adding to the costs that all Australians have to share-the cost of governmental intervention-we have to recognise that the major people involved in this area in the private sector-the major professionals, the major experts-have continually and consistently pressed for further major changes in this legislation. Senator Durack referred to the Law Council of Australia. Senator Haines listed a whole host of people, including the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills of which Senator Cooney, who I see is in the chamber, is a member. We share a role in that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —A splendid committee made up of splendid people.

—As Senator Haines quite properly says, it is a splendid committee which is alert to the adverse impact on individual rights and freedoms of some of the measures in this legislation. It is as a result of those concerns that that Committee has been involved in some correspondence with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and has in fact discussed at some length these major matters of principle.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me perhaps even more than the deliberations of this outstanding Committee is the fact that the Law Council of Australia-hardly an incompetent body-has raised major matters of concern which have not been addressed by the Government. I understand that the Law Council intends to comment, perhaps today, on the legislation as it now stands, and presumably temporarily stands because it is certainly among the most fluid legislation I have seen. It seems to be continually corrected-I do not use the word amended-for error and for misjudgment. However, in my view there are many misjudgments remaining in this legislation. The business law section of the Law Council has already expressed itself very forcefully to the Government on repeated occasions. It has provided briefings to honourable senators and honourable members of the other place. I stress that these are matters that the Law Council of Australia still considers must be resolved and should be resolved before this legislation really could be described as worth the cost in any sort of cost-benefit analysis. For example, the Law Council points out that it considers as errors, firstly, the imposition of a statutory warranty that would require a doctor to warrant that a patient would be cured or a lawyer to warrant that a client would not be convicted. Of course, in this case, most lawyers would at some stage of their career be subject to the very hefty penalties that this legislation provides.

The second error, according to the Law Council of Australia, relates to the reversal of the onus of proof in relation to representations made by a company and the consequences flowing from a representation deemed to be misleading. The third point that in the Law Council's view needs to be corrected is the new definition of what constitutes the use of monopoly power. The fourth point relates to the power of the Attorney-General to order the recall of a product without having to seek a court order. Later on I want to talk about administrative power and the extension of it beyond the bounds of rational and reasonable requirements of government.

The last point that the Law Council makes is the extension of the definition of a market in the context of takeovers to include a Territory. Of course, that probably reduces ad absurdum the nonsense of what really is a market that is capable of being affected under trade practices law. For example, the thought that the Australian Capital Territory-or the Northern Territory or any area of small population-is somehow discrete from, different from or unrelated to, say, Queanbeyan, is one of the classic nonsenses of this kind of legislation. The Australian Capital Territory, in marketing terms, in terms of access to alternative suppliers, comes nowhere near being a discrete market. This is one of the classic nonsenses that we should not have to put up with. Whenever one gets bureaucrats interfering in the market-place, one gets nonsense. This is a classic example of that kind of nonsense.

I will deal at some length with some of the points made by the Law Council of Australia because the reality is that the Government has rejected them. The people of Australia should be aware of the cogency, good sense and power of these arguments that the Government has decided to ignore. Of course, it may be that, in the last little document that was dumped on my desk a couple of minutes before I rose to speak, there are a couple of things that the Government is taking into account. If so, I certainly do not apologise. I simply ask that they be taken into account and it would have been nice to know that that was being done.

Let us deal in some detail with the argument that the Law Council of Australia has been making. In the Trade Practices Amendment Bill the Government has elected to allow the Attorney-General, on the advice of his Department, to make orders for the recall of products. I agree with the Law Council of Australia that it should be necessary for an order of the Federal Court of Australia to be obtained before any recall is implemented. I detest the existence of this kind of administrative power in view of the close relationships that appear to be capable of being developed between members of some governments and significant people in some areas of the business community. I find it unsatisfactory that this kind of power should reside without the capacity of adequate supervision. I certainly reject the concept. I am not suggesting that it is simply the possibility of corruption that should discourage us from allowing this kind of administrative fiat. I am just saying that in these situations the proper thing must be seen to be done as well as being done. Quite frankly, a secret advice by a bureaucrat to a Minister is totally inadequate when the consequences could be major damage to someone who is in fact doing no more than endeavouring to compete effectively and properly in a market-place. As the Law Council says, it would be better to involve the impartiality of the court than to have over-regulation of the activities of corporations through bureaucratic processes. The Law Council points out that in urgent cases the court can and does grant orders within a few hours if necessary.

The Law Council points out that, in the amendments proposed to section 46 dealing with monopolisation and section 84 dealing with the conduct of directors, servants or agents of corporations, the Government appears to be stifling entrepreneurial activity and limiting competitive behaviour. Section 46 is to be changed to prohibit corporations from engaging in competitive behaviour in a market where the corporation has a substantial degree of market power. Any amendment by the Government in this situation should clearly establish that the predatory purpose of a corporation cannot be inferred merely from the inevitable consequences of genuinely competitive conduct. That seems a rational, proper position and I support the Law Council in making it. For example, it says that profitable but low pricing by existing efficient manufacturers, which prevents less efficient competitors from entering the market-place, should not be interpreted as any abuse of market power and the Act should make it clear that predatory purpose can be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion. This is a classic example where the attempt to cure the problem may end up making the condition excessively worse.

The Law Council points out that under the existing law it is a breach of section 46 if a corporation, which is in a position to control or dominate a market, uses that power to affect a competitor. But under the proposed amendment the corporation, which has a substantial degree of market power and uses that power to affect a competitor, will be in breach. This seems to me to be a quite improper extention of the requirements. Depending on the market context, as the Law Council says, substantial power could in fact mean not a lot of power and corporations in that situation could be caught by section 46. So clearly, as the Law Council says, the thres- hold of competition, before active, energetic, competing corporations are affected, is clearly far too low in these governmental amendments. This problem, as the Law Council points out, is compounded by the proposed amendment to section 84 which would mean that if any servant or agent of a corporation behaved in a manner which could be regarded as being in breach of section 46 the corporation itself would be deemed to have engaged in that behaviour no matter how distant from the management the servant or agent is. That seems to me to be quite unreasonable and I agree with the Law Council that the reference to section 46 in section 84 is undesirable and that in fact the amendment to section 84 should not proceed at all.

In the takeovers area the Law Council points out that an amendment is proposed to extend the definition of a market to include a market in a Territory. I have dealt with this aspect, although I should point out that the Law Council underlines that this means that consideration of all future takeovers in Australia will have to have regard to the effect in the Australian Capital Territory-a miniscule market- if takeovers which otherwise might have a substantial public and economic benefit to Australia may be retarded simply because the takeover will have an effect in the Capital Territory. It might not have any effect in Queanbeyan but it may have an effect in the Australian Capital Territory and therefore should not take place. As I said earlier, that is an absolute nonsense; a classic example of the consequences of bureaucratic intervention in market places. These actions, as have been pointed out many times in the past, have an equal and opposite reaction. The reaction to this kind of legislation is that it in fact causes a nonsensical situation to develop.

Like the Law Council of Australia, I believe that section 51A which the Government proposes to add to the Act should be omitted but in view of time pressures I will not go on at length on this except to point out that where a company makes a representation relating to future matters without having reasonable grounds for making that representation, the representation under the new arrangements will be taken to be misleading and all civil and criminal consequences of its being misleading will follow. The Government proposes that the onus of establishing that the company had reasonable grounds for the representation rests with the company and not with the prosecution. I have a general view about the reverse onus of proof, which I believe is the proper view, and it rejects the proposition put up by the Government. This reversal of the onus of proof is clearly objectionable. The Law Council says:
. . . because it reverses the onus of proof, it deems a representation misleading even if it ultimately is proved true.

Of course it is unnecessary, as a series of legal cases makes clear. This is naturally a matter that concerns the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, and it has been the subject of some discussion. No doubt when the Committee's report is presented tomorrow-unfortunately tomorrow rather than today-these concerns will be adequately dealt with and we will have the opportunity of raising these important issues in the context of what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee does say.

The Law Council of Australia sensibly believes that the proposed amendment to section 84 should be withdrawn insofar as it has undesirable consequences for the relationship between professional persons and their clients. The amendment would impose, for example, on engineers, accountants, architects, lawyers, doctors, dentists and many other professionals-I suppose we could say that many of them are in the small business sector-a statutory warranty that their services will achieve whatever result the client desires. This is tantamount to a warranty, as I said earlier, by a doctor that a patient will be cured or by an architect that an innovative design will work. Under this proposal, Mr Joern Utzon would have found himself in great difficulty when it was evident that within a few years his design of shells for the Sydney Opera House simply would not have worked, and the whole structure had to be redesigned on different engineering principles. The roof now looks nothing like the roof that Mr Utzon considered would stand up. He designed a roof with a six inch shell; instead of that it now has six feet thick beams. Once again this is a nonsense.

Although the Act would not affect all professional services, the Law Council points out that, provided on a personal basis within a State, it would apply to incorporated professional practices in the States and to those and individual practices in the Territories. As the Law Council says, the common law requires that a professional use due care and skill, and if negligent a professional can be sued for damages. Why do we need this added bureaucratic burden? Senator Haines said that it is to protect small business. What absolute nonsense. The major objections to this legislation do not bear on these amendments to any great degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not refer to them in this regard, not on this matter.

—I know the section; Senator Haines said that the amendments in general were great, and one of the reasons they were great was that small business needs protecting, and she asked what the Opposition would do about it. I am pointing out that many of the objections to these amendments do not bear on the protection of small business. In this case they are to the clear disadvantage of people who could well be described as running small businesses. The Law Council points out that the proposed change would impose substantial burdens on professionals the majority of whom, as the Council says, operate small businesses. The Law Council makes the interesting point that the amendments would also stifle innovation in medicine, architecture, engineering and other professions. The Law Council believes there is no need or demand for the proposed changes and they should not proceed. I would be interested to hear the Government's case for these amendments in the context of the protection already presented by the common law.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I want to make a couple of points. Firstly, I believe that the Government owes it to the Senate and certainly to the people of Australia to explain why the objections by such a responsible, sensible and competent body as the Law Council of Australia and its Business Law Section have been rejected. The Government owes that explanation to us and I hope that the Senate will not be satisfied until it hears such an explanation. Clearly it would be nonsensical in this situation for the Senate to pass these amendments as they stand, and the suggestion of Senator Durack that they be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would certainly give the Government an opportunity to explain in great detail-the detail that is required-why these objections and certainly the objections that I hope tomorrow will come from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, among many others, are to be ignored. Certainly that would also give us the opportunity to develop the points that Senator Haines quite rightly raised about the perception of small business that some elements of these amendments would be useful to small business. We have to see the extent to which this burden of benefit exists.

It is worth referring to another publication of the Law Council of Australia which comments on the Green Paper. We all remember that, arising out of the Green Paper on trade practices, the Government rushed ahead with a set of amendments to remove sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. Honourable senators will remember that that did not proceed because the Senate did not pass the legislation. On that occasion-one of the few-the Australian Democrats saw the merit--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was one of their sensible lapses.

—As my friend Senator Puplick says, it was one of their sensible lapses from the norm where they supported the Opposition in preventing the removal of sections 45d and 45e of the trade Practices Act. I remind the Senate that had section 45d been removed, as the Government sought to do, the Mudginberri situation could never have been resolved to the benefit of the workers at Mudginberri, the owners of Mudginberri and the Australian people as a whole in terms of our export income. It is hypocrisy for members of the Government, particularly the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), to say that the Government had supported the maintenance of the law in this case. That law would not have existed if the Government had had its way.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by referring to another document the Law Council provided which dealt with some elements of the case being made by some people in small business that these amendments are required to protect small business. The Law Council states:

. . . the proper objective of Part IV of the Act is to foster an environment of competition for the health and vitality of the market place. That environment is one of continuous challenge where those less capable of competing not only may fail but should fail in the larger interests of the community. Their participation in the market should not be preserved artificially.

We on this side of the House say amen to all that. If that is the goal, it is appropriate when examining section 49 of the Act to inquire why a succession of governments, which included us in the past, has given that section so high a profile in their small business policies. It may be asked, more particularly: How significant for small business is the problem of price discrimination by comparison with the plethora of other problems confronting small business, particularly the problems created by the present Government as a result of its extraordinary reliance on monetary policy-high interest rates-to regulate the economy rather than adopting the more sensible proposals we have been recommending.

The Law Council questions whether either form of section 49 is framed in a way that will catch the conduct involved in the most commonly cited example of price discrimination antipathetical to small business, that is, the larger discount given to a grocery chain store or multi-branch enterprise with buying power. It is accepted that a consequence of the conduct may be a demonstrated consumer preference for the chain grocery stores over the corner shop and that the preference may be because of the better prices offered by the former. However, that consequence of lower prices to the consumer is one of the very objects of competition policy. Does it really matter how it came about? The Law Council argues that the consequence is one of competition-competition as to price between the various chains and as to price versus services and convenience between the chains and the corner shop. In other words, there are factors in competition other than price. Convenience and service at the corner shop are clear elements that are not considered when simply price factors are taken into account in this case.

Page 10 of the Law Council document quite sensibly outlines the specific disadvantages that may well flow to small business as a result of this kind of legislation. I regret that time is running out and I do not have the opportunity to outline them in detail. Perhaps other speakers on our side of the Parliament will do so. I stress that the Law Council quite sensibly makes the point that the provisions are likely to have harmful consequences to some small businesses, most probably to those which are the more innovative and ambitious. Many of those consequences will flow from the search by businessmen and their lawyers for safe responses to the provisions. The safest course of all is to arrange affairs so that there is no price differential. I find it unfortunate that the Government has decided to reject the expert advice given to it across such a wide field of this community. I strongly support Senator Durack's recommendation that this matter should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I urge the Australian Democrats to take a broader approach than the one they are now taking and to recognise the merit of the Opposition's case and that of so many professional expert bodies which have objected strongly to this legislation and which have been totally ignored by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Act and the intended amendments to it are aimed at the creation of a good climate of competition in trade and business and the protection of consumers of goods and services. They are the two central purposes of the legislation. Senator Michael Baume, in a stirring speech, criticised with great force particular sections of the Act. I am interested simply to go through some of those sections. It is a rather dry way of proceeding, but I am a little concerned. Senator Baume says that section 74, in effect, allows a client to demand of a professional whatever he wants and that, if the professional does not come up with that, there is all sorts of trouble for that professional or supplier of goods. The section, in fact, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In every contract for the supply by a corporation-
Senator Baume pointed out that the section was confined to a corporation-

in the course of a business of services to a consumer there is an implied warranty that the services will be rendered with due care and skill and that any materials supplied in connection with those services will be reasonably fit for the purpose for which they are supplied.
That states the common law position. Senator Baume frankly and candidly said that was so. So section 74 (1) is hardly a revolutionary piece of legislation. It simply sets out the common law position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we need legislation to do that?

—We need to because it is done in a context of what in effect is a code for conduct in this area. Indeed, a similar sort of thing has been done with State legislation such as the sale of goods Act in Victoria. The legislation is not unusual and takes the same approach in this respect as does legislation typified by the sale of goods Act. Section 74 (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a corporation supplies services to a consumer in the course of a business and the consumer, expressly or by implication, makes known to the corporation any particular purpose for which the services are required or the result that he desires the services to achieve, there is an implied warranty that the services supplied under the contract for the supply of the services and any materials supplied in connection with those services will be reasonably fit for that purpose or are of such a nature and quality that they might reasonably be expected to achieve that result, except where the circumstances show that the consumer does not rely, or that it is unreasonable for him to rely, on the corporation's skill or judgment.

That is a paraphrasing of sections 17, 18, 19 and so on of the sale of goods Act in Victoria which, as I understand it, is a typical piece of legislation in the common law world. All it says is that, if a person makes his requirements known to another person and relies on that person's skill and judgment, it is only proper that the goods or services should be provided to the best of the skill and ability of the supplier. As I see it, it is not legislation which in any way imposes a heavier onus upon people. It is acceptable in the general understanding of this community, which understanding has a history in the common law and in other legislation like this. Section 74 really is not the draconian legislation that it might otherwise have been thought to be from the statements by Senator Michael Baume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we have extended it?
—We have not in any horrific or draconian way. As I see it, it certainly does not give any basis for the fears expressed by the Law Council of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to proposed new section 46. Perhaps if one reads it loosely it will seem to be onerous, but if one reads it as, in my view, it is meant to be read it makes a lot of sense. Clause 16 of the Bill, which if passed will be section 46 of the Act, states:
A corporation that has a substantial degree of power in a market shall not take advantage of that power for the purpose of-
I emphasise very strongly the words `for the purpose of'-
eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor of the corporation or of a body corporate that is related to the corporation in that or any other market;

It is said that this is not so much an attack on the lack of competition or, to put it in a positive way, that it does not seek to encourage competition so much as seek to attack a particular competitor within the field; but if one reads the proposed new section one sees that it must be interpreted so as to lend protection to other people who are legitimately in a field to stay in the market-place. It is a legitimate section aimed at one person, one body or one corporation using its power for the purpose-it has to be for this purpose-of crushing competition. Proposed new section 46 (1) (b) makes that clear. It states that a corporation must not use its substantial power to prevent the entry of a person into that or any other market. Again, that is a thing which fair-minded people in the community would say ought to happen. A person should not be prevented from entering into a field of competition simply because someone with a substantial degree of power takes action to prevent that person from going in.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if it is an unintended consequence?

—If somebody went ahead and expanded a business and took action for the purpose of providing the market-place with better goods and services and it was a legitimate action in the sense that it was being done simply to expand his, its or her position in that market-place, that would not be the purpose delineated in that section and that would be legitimate. That, of course, is a decision for a particular court to make. Certainly it is not a section that should be used simply to stop somebody with entrepreneurial and managerial skills from expanding his business by that very process. If one looks at sub-clause (7) of clause 16, which is the other sub-clause about which a great deal of concern has been expressed, one sees this:

SPEECH.PARA: Without in any way limiting the manner in which the purpose of a person may be established for the purposes of any other provision of this Act a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.

The thing to know about that is that it is not a peremptory clause. It simply enables a tribunal or a court to come to a conclusion as to whether or not a corporation had breached the provisions of proposes new section 46 (1) (a), to para- phrase it, by looking at the conduct of the corporation itself, and that is legitimate. It may well be said: `What conclusions can be drawn simply from the conduct of a corporation?' As I understand it, one of the objections is that, simply because there has been an expansion of a particular corporation in a field, the expansion is evidence and is subject to the provisions of this Act. That is not so. It simply means that if one looks at the conduct of a corporation and all that it has done, if one looks at the way in which it has gone about expanding its presence in the market-place and if one looks at the way in which it has used or misused other people in trying to get into the field, that can be evidence from which the court may draw an inference and then come to a conclusion that that corporation has breached proposed new section 46. In my view there is nothing evil or draconian about that.

There has been an attack generally on regulations and the idea of regulating business. Indeed, this has been the subject of a lot of debate in this chamber. It has been pointed out that there should be less and less regulation. That having been said, much emphasis is given to section 45d of the Act as being a very salutary provision. We really cannot have it both ways. We cannot say: `It is proper to regulate some organisations in the community and it is not proper to regulate others'. The Mudginberri dispute and the impact of section 45d upon that situation has been mentioned in this Senate. Is it the intention of honourable senators opposite simply to abolish regulation not only against business but also against the unions, because that is the sort of thing that might well lead to a trade-off between those bodies. When we think of what that would lead to it is proper to say: `Of course the Parliament has to enter into that field and introduce proper regulation'. Indeed, as I understand it overall, even though people have said at times in the course of their speeches that we ought to get rid of regulations, what is really meant is that we ought to get rid of unnecessary regulations and that, of course, is a harder thing to debate than the general proposition that there ought to be an elimination of all regulations. If we look at the original Act of 1974 and the two things that are central to it, we see first of all that it deals with restrictive trade practices and, secondly, consumer protection. When we look at the sub-headings under Part IV dealing with restrictive trade practices, would anybody say that there should not be some sanctions on contracts, arrangements or understandings restricting dealings or affecting competition?. Would anybody deny that that is a proper consideration for this Parliament and a proper subject matter for this Act? Would anybody deny that arrangements that are reached to maintain prices should not be curtailed in some way? Would people say that covenants affecting competition should be allowed to flourish or covenants relating to prices should be allowed to operate? What do people say about boycotts? What do they say about the prohibition of contracts, arrangements or understandings affecting the supply or acquisition of goods or services? What do they say about monopolisation and so on? When we come to consumer protection, what do people say about misleading or deceptive conduct? Do we want to endorse that? Is it the intent of those who go in for deregulation to allow false representations, the offering of gifts and prizes, bait advertising and pyramid selling? When one looks at this, just what is objected to?

It is all very well for the Law Council of Australia or any other body to say that this is the way in which we should interpret this section or that sub-section, but, with great respect to those bodies, that is a misreading of what the legislation is all about because it has to be looked at in terms of its overall thrust which is, first of all, to create a proper atmosphere of competition and, secondly, to give protection for consumers. Senator Haines said that she did not think anybody had objected to clause 5 (b) of the Bill which amends section 4B in the Act, but unfortunately there has been some objection from the Australian Council of Professions which, in writing to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said:

At a meeting of representatives of various constituent bodies of the Council which took place today, proposed amendments to the Trade Practices Act were discussed. I am writing to say that the Council supports the submissions made by the Law Council of Australia, by the Royal Australian Institute of Architects and by the the Association of Consulting Engineers. . . . I refer in particular to clause 5 (b) and 38 of the Bill. The Council believes that the changes in the limiting amounts from $15,000 to $40,000 will have the effect of seriously increasing the onus placed upon many professionals in relation to the warranty implied in section 74 (2). The consequences may seriously prejudice the continued viability of many professional organisations.

Why should a move from $15,000 to $40,000 have such a drastic effect when the consumer price index has moved up over the years since that provision was made? Why is an objection taken to that? Why do people accept $15,000, yet object to $40,000 in present terms? How does that bring the consequences they talk about? The simple explanation is that it indicates that the protections given to consumers affect other people and in certain circumstances perhaps effects them adversely, but surely the concept of consumer protection requires us as a Parliament at least to keep up with modern prices. The criticisms of this Bill have to be looked at in detail to see just how real are their effects upon the sorts of things we should be talking about. Senator Haines said that the legislation gives protection to small business, that it simply indicates her ability as a visionary to understand just exactly what it is all about, and that it is not an anti-business Bill but, to the contrary, allows small business entry into a field which may otherwise be dominated and overtaken by big business.

Senator Durack spoke about the unconscionable contract. He said that that was a concept which would give the legal profession a bonanza and that it would be better to leave it to the High Court and the common law to determine these issues. It seems to me to be a contradiction in concepts to say, on the one hand, that we should not have legislation because it will lead to litigation and, on the other hand, to say that we need litigation to develop the law. We cannot have it both ways. He said that the High Court will develop proper rules and regulations in this area. Of course, that is a very piecemeal way of going about things. The High Court has to have the opportunity, first of all, to make the law. The cases on which it can exercise its judgment do not come before it with regularity or in a form which enables the laws to be made, and it is much neater or has much more force to leave the whole business to this Parliament. In fact that is what this Parliament has done over the years and what other parliaments have done over many years.

Senator Durack attacked the increase in regulation, the crushing burden of regulation, and he and Senator Baume mentioned the fact the cost of this regulation is $1 billion. I ask those opposite just how that $1 billion is worked out, because in some of the articles in which these sorts of figures are cited the cost of tariff protection has been included in the cost of regulation. I would like that clarified by Senator Durack and Senator Baume when they speak in Committee, because if they include the cost of tariff protection in that $1 billion cost of regulation the effect of what they say is very much weakened. Those high figures having been cited, I think it proper that their break-up be put before the Senate.

Again in Committee it would be interesting to hear whether Senator Durack says that there ought to be any regulation at all. At times he seemed to come close to saying that there ought to be complete self-regulation of industry. If somebody asked me whether it was best to have self-regulation, I would say that of course it is best to have self-regulation in every area if it will work, but those opposite should read the books of Dickens and the works of Henry Lawson pertaining to the situation in the nineteenth century when there was no regulation. I repeat: It is not a question of whether there ought to be regulation but of the sort of regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The threat of regulation is always more effective than the regulation itself.

—One of the great difficulties with this question of regulation or self-regulation is that the old adage that everybody is human is absolutely correct. When organisations and bodies are left to self-regulate they sometimes fail to come up with adequate protection. I think it was Senator Michael Baume or Senator Durack who said that safety ought to be left to the States. Leaving that aside, if there were no safety regulations there would be more horrific accidents than at present, there would be a higher compensation bill and there would be social suffering on a gigantic scale. The situation is that government has had to intervene in the work-place to give protection. If the worker in the work-place needs protection, does not the consumer in the market-place need protection? Are people going to act differently towards, say, workers in the work-place than towards the consumer in the market-place if there is no regulation?

SPEECH.PARA: I think it was said on the other side that section 45d was effetive insofar as it applied to unions. My view is that that sort of thing ought to be put into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act because the sorts of things sought to be achieved by section 45d in relation to industrial relations could be better achieved in that context. Nevertheless, the point I want to make in this context is that everybody in the debate so far has agreed that there ought to be some regulation of some people in some circumstances, whether in the market place, in the industrial relations field or elsewhere.

To sum up, this amendment continues the realisation of the concepts behind the Act and it very much deserves, as Senator Haines has so eloquently said, the support of the Senate. At the Committee stage of the debate I would like Senator Durack and Senator Baume to come up with a breakup of the figures of the cost of regulation because it seems that that is one of the crucial points of this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill is a significant Bill in that it will bring about changes in a number of areas which are vital to the operation of the Australian business community. Unlike Senator Cooney, members of the Opposition believe that the thrust of this Bill is antithetical to the interests of Australian business and that it is an anti-business piece of legislation. As I have said, the amendment Bill is a significant piece of legislation. It represents the final culmination of the Government's response to the February 1984 Green Paper and in many respects it traces its antecedents back to the recommendations of the Trade Practices Consultative Committees-the Blunt Committee in May 1979 and in December 1979 which dealt respectively with questions in relation to primary production and small business and its relation to the Trade Practices Act. In some respects it stretches back to the arguments first developed in the report of the Swanson Committee, the Trade Practices Act Review Committee, in August 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically this legislation contains the following elements: It introduces a new Division 1A in Part V which deals with aspects of consumer protection. They have been covered by Senator Durack in his speech and I do not intend to dwell on any of those sections in my contribution to the debate. The legislation makes changes in the operation of section 46 which deals with the misuse of market power, changes in the operation of section 50, which deals with mergers and other acquisitions and it introduces two significant sections, section 50A, which relates to the operation and effect of acquisitions outside Australia in relation to the operations of trade practices legislation, and a new section 52A which deals with aspects of unconscionable conduct by corporations. Perhaps I should also mention that one very small clause-clause 5(a)-brings into the operation of the Act coverage of matters relating to commercial road vehicles which arises from the recommendations of the May inquiry and is one of the parts, as Senator Durack indicated earlier in his address, that taken in isolation we would have no objection to.

I think it is interesting to go back and look briefly as the intended role of trade practices legislation in Australia. One has to go back to December 1962 to a statement which was made in the House of Representatives by the then Acting Attorney-General on behalf of the Attorney-General of the day, Sir Garfield Barwick. Sir Garfield said this:

As the House is aware, I have been engaged for some time in considering the need for legislation to control monopoly and restrictive practices in the business community of Australia and in devising a scheme of legislation which would protect free enterprise against such of these practices as were harmful to it.
He continued:
. . . the Government desired to protect and strengthen free enterprise against tendencies to monopoly and restrictive practices in commerce and industry.
Subsequently he stated:

The primary prerequisite of such a scheme is machinery that can be effectively used to halt practices which deprive, or tend to deprive, the community of the benefits of free enterprise and the individual trader of business opportunities that ought fairly to be open to him.

The whole thrust of what Sir Garfield Barwick was saying at that stage was that the old Restrictive Trade Practices Act was designed to increase the ability of the free enterprise system to operate against certain practices, in particular, practices of a restrictive and monopolistic nature, which were likely to have the effect of reducing the efficiency and capacity of Australian business to operate.

Sir Garfield made much of the term `free enterprise' and assigned a central position in what he was saying to the role of the market in allocating resources. The Blunt Committee in its May 1979 report on the operations of the Trade Practices Act in Relation to Primary Production in Australia had this to say:

The Trade Practices Act is an important instrument of economic policy, Part IV of which has the objective of prohibiting anti-competitive conduct which works against the efficient and economic allocation of resources in Australian markets. The general principle is that it is the market, rather than particular sectional interests, which should allocate resources.

My friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume in his contribution to this debate drew attention to the consequences which flow from attempted intervention in the operations of the market which has been given the necessary minimum degree of protection against monopolistic and restrictive practices.

First I turn to consider elements of clause 46 of the legislation which relate to the misuse of market power. Definitions have changed and been proposed for change in terms of the threshold at which this clause in its administrative provision should operate. The old Act provided, in its words, `that action should be taken where a company or a corporation was in a position substantially to control the operations within a market'. The Small Business and the Trade Practices Act report, the second of the Blunt Committee reports which deals with small businesses and which came down in December 1979, used the term `substantial degree of market power'. Paragraph 9.24 of the report stated:

We think that if the words ``in a position substantially to control a market for goods or services'' were replaced by the words ``that has a substantial degree of market power'' the direction of the section's thrust would be clearer.

That found its way into the general debate but by the time the Green Paper had been produced a change was again proposed and the term `substantial control' was introduced in the discussion by the Green Paper. The legislation before us goes back basically to the original Blunt Committee recommendation in using the terminology `substantial degree of power in a market'. Of course any definition in legislation is bound to be fraught with complexities. In the third edition of the `Guidebook to Australian Trade Practices Law' at paragraph 705 the following comment is offered:

Before the provisions of sec. 46 will apply to a corporation, it must be ``in a position substantially to control'' a market for goods or services. This is a legal, not an economic concept; however in considering the position of the relevant corporation, one must look to economic concepts and consider the degree of market power which it possesses. The question of how much market power constitutes ``being in a position substantially to control'' a particular market is incapable of precise definition.

What we have is a series of legal artifices being brought into the regulation of essentially an economic situation and they are singularly inappropriate in some of these definitional questions. I shall return to that matter on a number of occasions. The second element which arises within section 46 is the question of the word `Purpose'. There have been great problems in attempting to define, once again, how the issue should be handled of determining the purpose of a practice undertaken by a corporation. Paragraph 28 of the Green Paper states:

There have been difficulties arising from the term ``purpose'' in existing section 46. It has introduced a highly subjective element into the operation of the provision. This difficulty is especially the case where it is necessary to prove the mental state of a corporation.

Later on in this legislation we shall see that, instead of the Government taking the road of attempting to be more precise, attempting to eliminate some of the subjectivity to which the Green Paper itself drew attention, it has in fact, in proposed sub-section (7) of section 46, expanded this by introducing a new test based upon inferences to be drawn.

The third area within the ambit of section 46 is, of course, the definition of the term `market'. This is a particularly vexed and complicated matter. The Swanson Committee, in its report of August 1976, made this comment:

Market definition is always of considerable importance. If the market is too widely defined it may be that the requisite effect upon competition cannot ever be shown, to the detriment of those seeking relief from a restrictive agreement or practice. Alternatively, if the market is too narrowly defined it may result in hardship to and unnecessary limitations upon business actions, such as inhibitions on exploiting novelty.

My colleague Senator Michael Baume has drawn attention to the fact that by including the reference to States and Territories in clause 17 (b) we in fact have drawn within this legislation a definition of `market' which is capable of being read as constituting for practical purposes the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory as a market and determining whether in fact practices should be allowed depending upon so narrow a test as far as that is concerned. I believe that, particularly in relation to the merger provisions, that definition is one which is beyond all commercial reality.

It is perhaps also to be noted that in clause 15 of the legislation we find that the existing words `a market' in section 45c of the principal Act are to be removed and in their place the words substituted `any market'. When I say it is capable of a very narrow definition, it is not to be thought that this has not already occurred in some respects. If one looks at the decision of the Federal Court of Australia in the case of O'Brien Glass Industries Ltd v. Cool and Sons Pty Ltd, one finds that the Federal Court in this instance chose to define the city of Wagga and its environs as being for all intents and purposes a market. The court said in part in its report:
A market is usefully viewed as a field of rivalry or close competition between firms.
It went on:
That both Bradley and O'Brien-
the companies concerned in the case-

operated throughout New South Wales (and beyond) does not imply that the State was the relevant market. Such a strict geographic definition ignores the view that the Wagga district was, in economic terms, a particular area of close competition between wholesalers.

So we get reduced to the level that particular towns, particular districts, may, for the purposes of this legislation, be regarded as a market and that consequences are to be allowed to flow from making a definition based upon something as narrow as what happens to affect trade or competition within Wagga and its environs, and that is then extended to have an operation perhaps throughout the whole of the State of New South Wales or, indeed, the whole of the Commonwealth of Australia.
One of the Government's responses and one of its additions to the legislation is the introduction of sub-section (7) of proposed section 46. That sub-section reads:

Without in any way limiting the manner in which the purpose of a person may be established for the purposes of any other provision of this Act, a corporation may be taken to have taken advantage of its power for a purpose referred to in sub-section (1) notwithstanding that the existence of that purpose is ascertainable only by inference from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.
The Law Council of Australia, in its comments on the legislation, has said this:
To the extent that a Court has always been entitled to infer purpose from conduct, 46 (7) only repeats the common law and is consequently unnecessary.
I agree with that. It goes on to say:
46 (7) should make it clear that predatory purpose may be inferred only from conduct inconsistent with any reasonable alternative conclusion.

I think that is a very telling point. The way in which proposed section 46 (7) is drawn is so wide that in fact it imposes upon the courts, upon the persons charged with the adjudication in this legislation, a responsibility to try to infer from what might be ordinary and legitimate commercial activity a purpose, depending on how the court or tribunal is minded to find at the time. The comments by the Law Council that in fact predatory purpose should be inferred only from conduct which is unusual conduct rather than ordinary operations of commercial reality is, I think, an extremely telling point.

The Business Council of Australia, in a submission which it made to the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, on 15 November 1985, commented that the changes to section 46 are substantial and, in its present form, the new section can only add to the confusion as to what constitutes legitimate competitive behaviour by companies with a substantial degree of market power. There again, I am very much in agreement with those comments by the Business Council. There is a degree of confusion, an additional degree of unnecessary confusion, introduced as a result of this new piece of legislation. The question of certainty, particularly certainty within the field of commercial transactions, is a most important one. In the tenth annual report of the Trade Practices Commission, for 1983-84, there is a section written by the retiring Commissioner, Mr Bannerman. In his very useful paper, at page 200 of that report, he refers at some length to the need for certainty and the need for business to operate within a climate of certainty. I do not believe that this will be achieved by the amendments which the Government is putting to the Senate at the moment.

I turn to section 50 of the previous legislation, which dealt with a situation in terms of mergers where, as a result of the acquisition, a corporation would be, or be likely to be, in a position to control or dominate a market for goods or services. The new section 50 provides that it is not so much `control or dominate' but simply to dominate a market for goods and services. It is quite clear that a variety of views has been expressed about the need to make further amendments to section 50. When Mr Bannerman retired as Chairman of the Commission, he made a number of comments about section 50. Basically, the thrust of those comments was that section 50 did not need any tinkering with, except in relation to matters arising from the creation of a joint venture, the so-called McComas amendment arising from the Bowral bricks case. Interestingly enough, Mr McComas, in an interview in his capacity as the new Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, as reported in the Australian Financial Review on 14 March 1985, also had some comments about section 50. He said:

Having allowed for our present state of affairs, section 50 in substantially the form it is, is consistent with government wishes to see a more efficient industrial sector and is consistent with a universal wish that Australia should be more internationally competitive.
The report goes on to say:
He-
that is, Mr McComas-
said he might look towards a minor alteration of the present section such as just having a domination threshold instead of control or domination, but otherwise the section would work.

As I have said, we have a domination rather than a control or domination situation, but I do not believe that the rest of the provisions of section 50 are in fact only the minor tinkering which ought to have been undertaken and which experts of the calibre of Mr Bannerman and Mr McComas were mentioning. Essentially, I believe that the operation of the new section 50 will be to inhibit those mergers which ought to be allowed to take place. It is, in fact, an anti-merger provision and I do not believe that that should be a major part of trade practices law in Australia. I believe that it is true that the achievement of monopoly or near monopoly power is not in itself anti-competitive, nor is it necessarily in all circumstances undesirable.

I believe that the anti-merger thrust of the legislation may well inhibit the rationalisation of Australian commercial operations which is necessary if the restructuring of Australian industry is to take place and the objects of better international competition are to be met. I believe that the size and nature of Australian markets differs from other markets and the high concentration is in some respects a necessary part of Australian markets in order to provide effective competition with overseas companies. I believe that there is a consistent threat of substitution and or import competition as well as new Australian competitors which will act as a check to the excess of market power. I believe that the legislation as proposed is otherwise inconsistent with the objectives of other important areas of Government policy, as I have said, in terms of rationalisation and restructuring of industry, foreign investment, trade policy and company law. The other matter which arises in terms of section 50 is the introduction of an association relationship with the introduction of the words `or associated with' in sub-section (2). Again, the Law Council of Australia draws attention to what it believes to be the negative consequences of such an enactment. I quote from its submission:

For example, if company A owns 15 per cent of the shares in company B and has one common director, it may be that A exercises an influence over B which is ``real and not merely nominal''. However, that influence may (and probably would) fall short of allowing A to make use of B's market power.

Nevertheless, I go on to say that the term `or associated with' would allow the Commission and the courts to make inferences which simply do not stand the test of real commercial operations. The Law Council gives an example. It says:

To take a current example it may well be the case that Mr Holmes a Court exercises a ``substantial influence'' over BHP. Certainly if he gets one director on the Board he is likely to. However, it would be unrealistic to assume that BHP's market power is his in toto. Why not pay regard to the actual kind and degree of influence he can actually exert.

The whole business of `associated with' in terms of sub-section (2) of this section is fraught with difficulties and is quite unnecessary. In terms of what we are trying to achieve with reasonable trade practices legislation, I believe that all of it can be achieved without these types of amendments to the Act. The critical determinant is the degree to which the Trade Practices Commission is prepared to play an activist role. I am sorry that in some respects it has not pursued a more activist role in one or two areas. For instance, if one looks at the annual report of 1984-85, and in particular the lengthy discussion which starts on page 14 dealing with the Tradestock Pty Ltd case, there is a good ground for arguing that it is a pity that the decision made by His Honour Mr Justice Franki was not challenged and was not pursued more vigorously. At the same time the Trade Practices Commission has acted in certain areas with a commendable degree of vigour. I look, for instance, at the determination of October 1984 on the International Air Transport Association application for essentially a price fixing arrangement-I suppose one should say a fare fixing arrangement in this case-where, at page 93 of the report, the Commission said quite positively:
The Commission is of the view that tariff compliance machinery agreed between airlines (be it directly sponsored by IATA or, like YIP-
that is the yield improvement program-
consistent with the IATA rules) does not provide public benefit.

Within the existing framework of the Act there is plenty of scope for the Commission to pursue the sort of activist protection of consumer interests without the extensions which are, in fact, predicated in this legislation. I have no time to develop this point but I believe that new section 50a is a section which has the potential to inhibit Australian firms from pursuing an active role in acquiring assets, acquiring companies and acquiring a presence in overseas markets. It brings into the consideration of essentially domestic operations a series of tests related to acquisitions undertaken by Australian corporations outside the boundaries of Australia.

I would hope that the Government would be seeking to actively encourage Australian investment overseas. By way of example, a company with which I am particularly familiar, Boral, has had an active program of acquisition of companies, in particular in the sunbelt part of the United States-states like Arizona, New Mexico and California. It has been very active in the acquisition of brick companies in places like Georgia. It has been active in the United Kingdom in the acquisition of concrete pipe operations. I think it has expanded in a most commendable sense in overseas markets. It has established an Australian presence, which has benefited itself of course, but the Australian industry has also benefited from the technology transfer which has gone with that. It has established a reputation for a continuing excellence in terms of its product. I think that there is a real danger that the operation of section 50A may inhibit rather than promote these overseas acquisitions which ought to be encouraged within Australia's commercial sector.

The only comment I make about proposed division 1A of Part V in relation to consumer matters is to note that the Australian Council of Professions, which represents a number of professions in the medical, architectural, engineering, dental, veterinary, chemical, law, accountancy, chartered accountancy, surveying, pharmaceutical, actuarial and other professions, has indicated its very strong opposition to the change in clause 5 (b) and clause 38 of the Bill regarding the change from the liability of $15,000 to $40,000 to which Senator Cooney referred in the course of his address. Senator Cooney said that the increase was only in line with the consumer price index over that period of time. However, I believe that the Australian Council of Professions is right in drawing attention to the fact that it may, in its words, `seriously prejudice the continued viability of many professional organisations'.

The last point I make, which is a point that Senator Durack spent time developing, relates to the general level of inconsistency. The Government is saying that it is seeking to reduce the regulation of Australian business. Only last month it brought down a report entitled Review of Business Regulations, Information Paper No. 1 from the Business Regulation Review Unit, in which it indicated that there were certain priority areas-foreign investment, mineral export controls, model food law and standards, customs administration, Commonwealth collection of business statistics, national chemical notification and assessment scheme, building regulations, controls on financial institutions, transport and aviation regulations, primary industry regulations and the location of child care centres-which were high in its priority for reducing regulation, for reducing the burden of government imposts arising from regulation. Yet, on the other hand, in terms of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, the Government, having tried to say to Australian businesses that it is actually interested in the deregulation of a great deal of their operations-whether it is in the financial sector or elsewhere-that it is anxious to review business regulations, to reduce the burden and the impost on Australian business, nevertheless comes along with a piece of legislation which in a number of very sensitive areas substantially adds to the burden of regulation and to the cost which will flow from that.

That is not to say that there are not a number of areas in which close attention has to be paid to mergers and to the control of monopoly practices. One thinks of the recent mergers that have taken place, particularly within the retail food industry, as a possible example. Nevertheless, I believe, as the Opposition as a whole believes, that the thrust of this amendment Bill is decidedly anti-business, is decidedly antithetical to the interests of Australian business and is contrary to the desire of the Government, the Opposition and the whole business sector for greater rationalisation and greater efficiency in the business sector. It is for those reasons that the Opposition will oppose the Bill in toto although acknowledging that there are certain parts of it which are worthy of support. In particular we will be seeking the reference of this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for a more thorough examination of the possible consequences of a number of these proposals in the current legislation in the hope that the Government might be persuaded to do something about them to ensure that the efficiency of Australian business is not further impaired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment Bill, and the handling of it, provides a very good example of two things that responsible governments should not do. Firstly, they should not introduce legislation on which those in the community who will be most affected have had insufficient time for appropriate comment or input. Secondly, they should not rush legislation through the Parliament with no opportunity for reasoned or measured consideration. Yet the Government is guilty on both counts with this legislation when we consider its history through the House of Representatives last year. For example, concerning one of the important provisions of the Bill, the product recall provision, a white paper was put out by the Government-a discussion paper-on 21 June making various proposals about the proposed legislation and seeking reactions and submissions from business and other interested groups in the community by the end of August.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a very admirable procedure but what happened? Five weeks later the Bill was in the House of Representatives. Particularly given the nature of the submissions received-some were very detailed and important-no one can tell me that it would simply not be possible for relevant government departments, let alone the political process of government itself, to give those submissions due consideration and to get them into the Parliament within five weeks. That task really boggles the imagination, if the Government were really serious about taking account of the views put to it.

The Bill went before the House of Representatives on 9 October and subsequently in November it was steamrollered through the House along with the many other pieces of legislation that the Government pressurised through at the end of the last session. In fact, so eager was the Government to get that Bill through the House last year that it was circulating amendments to its own proposals on the very day that the Bill was debated and voted through the House. What a mockery that makes of the parliamentary processes.

I put it to the Government as a general proposition that if we are to have responsible and serious government in this country there must be a much greater regard for the due processes of consideration of the important issues of the day that affect us as a community or important sections of the community. We do ourselves and the democratic process a disservice by treating important legislation in the way we so frequently do. It is a criticism that can be made certainly of this Hawke Government but previous governments have not been exempt from such criticism. As parliamentarians, we have a responsibility to say to governments of whatever political persuasion: `Let us have a proper look at what we are doing'. If we do not, we will get bad government, bad laws and we will rightly deserve the opprobrium of the community which, I believe, the parliamentary process has at the moment.

This lack of appropriate consideration of the trade practices amendment legislation, which is a major legislative package, has merely reinforced the entrenched ideology of the Hawke Government by producing a Bill which is anti-business and, despite protestations to the contrary in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and in some of the contributions made in the Senate and the House, it is not only anti-business but also anti-consumer because of the cost implications. The cost of additional regulation has to be passed on. In the end it is the consumer who pays. We have an anti-business and anti-consumer piece of legislation because it is extremely costly. We do not have an exact costing of this legislation but it has been estimated that the direct cost to the business community will be of the order of $50m and could well be considerably higher.

We have a repeat of the old Australian Labor Party socialist philosophy that industry and the community can be improved by more and more regulation and involvement by government in telling sections of the community what to do and what is in their best interests. This Bill flies in the face of what the Government professed to be its concern to reduce business regulation over the last couple of years. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his 1984 election policy speech, less than 18 months ago, said:
