QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 11 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How is the disease Chlamydia Psittaci transmitted amongst koalas, and what is the incubation period of the disease.
(2) What is the normal titre of Chlamydia Psittaci in a koala.
(3) Is the exporting of koalas by the Australian Government exposing overseas zoo populations to a highly contagious and deadly disease.
(4) Can the Minister explain why Japanese zoos are able to obtain koalas when Australian sanctuaries are not.
(5) Will the Minister detail what funds the Government has allocated in the current financial year to koala research and habitat restoration.
(6) Which koalas died recently in Japan, and will the Minister provide:
(a) the veterinary reports made prior to despatch of the koalas to Japan; and
(b) the autopsy reports.
(7) Can the Minister provide a definition of ``captive populations'' of koalas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The mode of transmission of the disease organism Chlamydia psittaci is not known. In koalas the organism has been linked to diseases of the respiratory, reproductive and urinary systems and to eye diseases. There is evidence that the disease may be transmitted venereally, congenitally and by insects or dust particles.
The incubation period of the disease in koalas is not known.

(2) In this context, a titre is a measurement of the concentration of antibodies in the blood. Antibodies are produced by the animal in response to an infection, including infection by Chlamydia psittaci. The antibody titre of an uninfected animal would be zero. Once infection starts, the antibody titre increases at varying rates, sometimes up to 2000:1. Once the infection has been overcome, antibody levels decrease and often a residual antibody titre remains for some years. This residual titre could range from 4:1 to 64:1.
Thus the antibody titre of Chlamydia psittaci in a koala depends on whether or not the animal is infected and on the stage of infection.

(3) Before any koala is considered for export, tests must be conducted to establish it is free from an infection of Chlamydia psittaci. It is important to note that the organism Chlamydia psittaci is not confined to koalas in Australia, but is found in a large number of different species of animals and in a number of other countries around the world.

(4) The acquisition from Australia of koalas by Japanese and any other overseas zoos is governed by the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. This Act controls export of Australian native wildlife but does not regulate the acquisition of koalas by sanctuaries in Australia. Such activities are governed by the nature conservation laws of the States and Northern Territory. The honourable senator may wish to pursue his inquiries with the nature conservation authorities in the States and the Northern Territory.

(5) The Koala Conservation Program launched by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment in June this year, will address many of the deficiencies in our knowledge of koalas. American Express International has contributed $200,000 towards the program and the Government contribution includes the administrative costs, public awareness material and $20,000 for scientific research with a $10,000 forward commitment into 1986-87.
(6) One female koala died at Tama Zoo, Tokyo, and one female koala died at Kagoshima Zoo, Nagoya, Japan.

(7) If the honourable senator is referring to the use of the words `in captivity' as stated in Condition 6 of the Conditions for the Export of Koalas, which was tabled in Parliament in September 1984, these words require that any koala proposed for export must have been bred in captivity or held in captivity for at least 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Tasmanian Smelters Pty Ltd sought an export licence for the export of silicon.
(2) Is Tasmanian Smelters Pty Ltd a joint venture of Messrs Pechiney (40%) and Pioneer Concrete (60%), both of whom have subsidiaries operating in South Africa.
(3) Is Messrs Pechiney owned by the French Government.
(4) Is it in accord with Government policy to grant export licences to companies or joint ventures which operate subsidiaries in South Africa.

(5) Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce satisfied with the environmental record of the multinational corporation Pechiney in its Australian operations in the light of public protest in Newcastle (NSW) where water catchment is threatened by toxic wastes, and Electrona (Tas.) where residential amenity is threatened by industrial intrusion.
(6) Will the Minister be calling for an independent Environmental Impact Statement for the proposed silicon smelter at Electrona Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is assumed that the question relates to the issuing of restricted goods permits under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. As silicon is not covered by those regulations the need to obtain permission does not arise.

(2) Tasmanian Silicon Smelters Pty Ltd is a joint venture of Pechiney Australia Ltd, a subsidiary of Pechiney Asie Pacifique (40%) and Pioneer Concrete (60%). Pechiney advise that they have no subsidiary or activity whatsoever in South Africa.
(3) Pechiney Asie Pacifique was nationalised by the French Government in 1981.

(4) The Government has implemented certain economic and other measures in respect of South Africa and has introduced a code of conduct for Australian companies with commercial interests in that country. As mentioned in (1) above, silicon does not require an export permit but, in cases where such export permits are required, and the goods are not specifically affected by the measures introduced by the Government, normal procedures are followed and trade is permitted to continue whether or not the exporting company has direct commercial interests in South Africa.

(5) With respect to Commonwealth Government environmental requirements I am advised that Pechiney (Australia) Limited has met its obligations. The two projects which are mentioned are both under active consideration by the respective State Governments environment authorities. In New South Wales, the Minister for Environment and Planning has asked his Department to work with Pechiney to find `a satisfactory alternative site in a less environmentally sensitive location for waste disposal'. The silicon smelter proposal in Tasmania is currently before the Tasmanian Environment Protection Appeal Board for examination of environmental control measures which will be mandatory.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Mr Henderson of the CAI and Sir William Keys of the RSL both members of the 18 person National Consultative Committee of the International Year of Peace.
(2) Have both these people recently lent support to the PADEX 1986 Defence Show by having their organisations publicly support such an exhibition.
(3) Does support for such an exhibition in the International Year of Peace indicate a position diametrically opposed to the purposes of the celebrations.
(4) Will the Government remove these 2 people from the Consultative Committee in view of this conflict of interest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Sir William Keys lent support to PADEX '86 in his official capacity as National President of the RSL. I understand that the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) also supported the exhibition.

(3) The membership of the National Consultative Committee on Peace and Disarmament represents a broad range of community groups which have demonstrated a concern for peace and disarmament and which all have a contribution to make in raising community awareness of the IYP. It is to be expected that individual members of the Committee will have different points of view on the best means to achieve peace and disarmament and therefore also on such issues as the holding of the PADEX 1986 Defence Exhibition. The terms of reference for the Committee do not exclude its members holding such views.
(4) In view of the answer to (3) above, the question of removing people from the Committee does not arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who has been present at, or participated in each of the Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) meetings related to the Australia Card and at which meetings.
(2) Who has participated in each of the National Identification Numbering System (NINS) technological working group meetings related to the planning of the Australia Card and at which meetings.

(3) How many departments or agencies have made submissions to, or communicated attitudes to the IDC/NINS groups planning the Australia Card, and how many such submissions were presented by each organisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The following Departments/Authorities were represented on the Interdepartmental Committees and/or Working Parties which considered the Australia Card proposal:

Department of Health, Health Insurance Commission, Australian Taxation Office, Department of Social Security, Department of Community Services, Department of Veterans' Affairs, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Department of the Treasury, Department of Finance, Department of Special Minister of State, Attorney General's Department, Australian Federal Police, Australian Electoral Commission, Australian Bureau of Statistics, Department of Education, Department of Foreign Affairs, Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

(3) While formal submissions were not sought from departments or agencies by the Interdepartmental Committee, the nature of the IDC process is such that all departments represented made a contribution to the work of the committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs provide information about the effect on Australia-Papua New Guinea relations following the change of government which took place on 21 November 1985.
(2) What is the present level of Australian aid to Papua New Guinea.
(3) How does the present level of aid compare to years 1982-83, 1983-84 and 1984-85.
(4) How will Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea be affected by the sudden demise of the Somare administration in political, financial and diplomatic terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The change of Government in Papua New Guinea on 21 November confirms the commitment of that country to democratic processes, a commitment I have applauded on numerous occasions. In sending messages of congratulations to Prime Minister Wingti, the Prime Minister and I looked forward to working with our Papua New Guinea counterparts to support the very close and co-operative relationship that exists between our two countries. The Prime Minister extended an invitation to Mr Wingti to visit Australia.
(2) The estimated total of Australian aid to PNG in 1985-86 is $326,386,000. Of this $302,799,000 will be supplied as direct budget support.
(3) The following table compares the current level of Australian aid to PNG with the level of aid supplied over the past three years.
AUSTRALIAN AID TO PNG 1982-83 to 1985-86: CURRENT AND CONSTANT PRICES

(4) I have every reason to believe that there will be a substantial measure of continuity in policy in Papua New Guinea, including in matters which bear directly on that country's relations with Australia.

In my address to the University of Papua New Guinea on 7 November I noted that Australia is part of Papua New Guinea's region and cannot escape relevance to it: our policies in a great number of ways impact on each other. I also expressed my understanding of Papua New Guinea's pursuit of self-reliance and of the fact that the PNG Government might wish to seek new directions offering better prospects of bringing benefit to its people.

I met Mr Wingti in July and again in November. The Prime Minister met him in September. Mr Wingti has considerable Ministerial experience, including more than two years as Deputy Prime Minister, and we have had useful discussions with him on a range of issues.

The Prime Minister and I have both sent messages of appreciation and admiration to Mr Somare for his historic role in his country's development, and for his contribution to good relations between Papua New Guinea and Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Communications indicate in what circumstances and in what form Telecom issues a written apology to subscribers who have been overcharged for their telephone service (see answer to Question on Notice No. 265, Hansard, 5 November 1985, p. 1598).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: It is Telecom's practice where an error occurs to apologise for any inconvenience which may have been caused and in appropriate cases to endeavour to rectify the situation. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) By what authority are appointments to the Arts Development Board made.
(2) What number of people may be appointed to the Arts Development Board.
(3) What particular expertise is required in an appointee to the Arts Development Board.
(4) How many people comprise the current board.
(5) What new appointments have been made since 31 July 1985.
(6) What new appointments are to be made before 30 June 1986.
(7) What is the term of these appointments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following response has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Appointments are made by the Minister for Territories under his executive authority.
(2) The Board's charter provides for a maximum of nine members, including a representative of the Department of Territories.

(3) The Board's charter requires membership to include four persons who practise or have practised in the Arts, and each of the theatre, music, visual, and community arts to be represented. In considering appointments to the Board, the Minister for Territories takes into account the nominees' personal interests, qualities, and attributes for the work of the Board, and also the particular needs of the Board at the time; for example, maintaining a reasonable balance of art-form representation.

(6) Two new appointments are under consideration (as at 13 January 1986). The terms of four members will expire in April 1986. Consideration has not yet been given to the filling of the ensuing vacancies.
(7) Two years, although members may be re- appointed for a further term of two years at the Minister's discretion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will an ID card prevent the development of new evasion industries such as moving funds off-shore to avoid the effects of the ID system, or strengthen an underground employment market for illegal immigrants.

I believe that it would be unreasonable to divert resources from the preparation of the submission to attempt to provide the substantial amount of information sought in the question. The Government's submission will be made available to members and senators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs indicate whether Australia has made any representations to Britain requesting a reconsideration of its decision to withdraw from UNESCO which is due to be reviewed this November.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On several occasions in recent weeks the Australian Government urged the United Kingdom Government to reconsider its decision to withdraw from UNESCO. During November, representations were made on a bilateral basis and Mr Parsons, our High Commissioner in London, took part with other Commonwealth High Commissioners in joint representations to the British Government.
Despite these efforts, on 5 December the United Kingdom confirmed its intention to withdraw from UNESCO. This decision took effect on 31 December 1985.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the growth in establishment of digital radio concentrator systems over the next few years in Western Queensland be negated by failure to establish adequate repair and service facilities.
(2) Can the Minister investigate the feasibility of establishing a repair service for digital radio concentrator systems in appropriate ``central'' locations, e.g. Roma, Longreach, Mount Isa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An adequate maintenance organisation is being established to service the Digital Radio Concentrator Systems (D.R.C.S.).
(2) There will be three levels of maintenance established.

First level maintenance will be provided by the network of country technician stations existing now. The work will be mainly confined to identification and replacement of the faulty/suspect unit using aids such as the supervisory system and specially designed test equipment.

Second level maintenance will be provided by trained radio staff at the established Radio Centres. Generally this work will involve more complex faults on repeaters and exchange units. Radio Centres which will have D.R.C.S. responsibilities exist at Townsville, Rockhampton, Mount Isa, Mackay, Emerald and Roma.

Third level maintenance concerns the repair of faulty modules. This is a specialist task requiring not only highly specialised equipment but also controlled environmental conditions in which to work. Initially this work (termed panel repair) will be carried out by the manufacturer NEC. Telecom will establish a national Panel Repair Centre in Brisbane at a subsequent time thus allowing for an orderly build up of the required skills and facilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 3 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Department of Resources and Energy liaise with the Queensland Government in investigating the security of the Ben Lomond stockpile, which has been abandoned by total mining with only a temporary cover and occasional security checks.
(2) Can both Federal and State Governments ensure that total mining appropriately secure this stockpile in accordance with Federal Government requirements, as this stockpile is in a remote area.

(3) Can the Minister for Resources and Energy advise about the future of the Ben Lomond site in regard to completely cleaning up this area, in view of reported environmental deficiencies identified in total minings proposal of November, 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) I refer the honourable senator to my answer to her question without notice about Ben Lomond on 2 December 1985. I must emphasise that Total Mining Australia holds two valid mining leases over the deposit from the Queensland Government. While Total Mining Australia ceased to work at the site some years ago the site has not been abandoned as is suggested in the honourable senator's question. As the ore at the site has not been concentrated or processed in any way no safeguards apply and the Commonwealth has no responsibility for the leases issued by the Queensland authorities over the area, or anything on them.

As I advised in my reply of 2 December 1985, Total Mining is required to comply with the codes of practice relating to radiation protection and radioactive waste management as developed under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act. Officers of my Department have consulted with the Queensland authorities on this matter and their advice is that:
Total Mining's activities at Ben Lomond are monitored on a continuing basis to ensure that the conditions required by the codes are complied with.

The question of ultimate rehabilitation of the area on the expiry or relinquishment of Total Mining Australia's leases is a matter for the Queensland Government through the conditions imposed in the mining leases. It would appear that this question is unlikely to become topical for some years as both leases have some considerable period to run, and Total Mining Australia has given no sign of any intention of surrendering them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 3 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what circumstances are applicants for a grant under the First Home Owners Scheme required to supply bank books and other documents which detail savings over the past 12 months, and to provide an explanation for ``major'' deposits.
(2) Have these circumstances been altered since the inception of the Scheme; if so, what changes in assessment rules requiring this follow-up have been made, and when.
(3) What is the estimated proportion of cases in which these extra details have been sought in each State and Territory in each of the financial years 1983-84, 1984-85 and 1985-86 to date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no requirement for applicants to have held qualifying savings under the First Home Owners Scheme. However, in order to satisfy the requirements of the First Home Owners Act, applicants may be asked to provide evidence that they have, or will have, adequate financial resources to complete the purchase or construction of their first home.

In some other cases, details of the financial resources of an applicant including savings records, are required to satisfy the Assessment Officer that all parties to the home acquisition have joined in the FHOS application, or confirm other information which could be linked with the income test or previous home ownership.

(3) A significant proportion of applications result in requests to the applicant for additional information on some aspect of the application. However no detailed statistics covering the nature or number of such requests are maintained by the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 4 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers of the Australian Federal Police have been detailed to investigate matters related to the presence of the yacht Ouvea:
(a) on Norfolk Island; and
(b) elsewhere.

(2) Are any of these enquiries continuing; if so, how many people are still investigating such matters; if not, how many staff hours were devoted to these matters, when was the investigation completed and upon whose instructions, and what written reports were furnished to the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It should be stressed that the investigation into the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior is one begun in New Zealand (NZ) and which was and remained the responsibility of NZ authorities to investigate. The investigation was never within the Australian Federal Police's (AFP) area of responsibility. The honourable Senator would appreciate that the AFP has no basis for making inquiries in Australia except in relation to breaches of Commonwealth law or in response to requests for assistance from overseas agencies. The AFP has extended every co-operation to the NZ authorities in their investigation and it has complied with all requests for assistance.

(1) (a) All three members of the AFP who serve as sworn members of the Norfolk Island Police under the jurisdiction of the Administrator of the Island assisted NZ Police in investigations on the Island during the Ouvea's presence there.
(1) (b) A number of AFP members on duty at the time at Sydney Airport and the AFP's Regional Headquarters in Redfern assisted NZ Police in their investigations in Australia.
(2) AFP ceased any active involvement in this investigation on 17 July 1985. However, there are some AFP enquiries being conducted on behalf of the NZ Police through Interpol.
During the time AFP assisted NZ Police in their investigations, approximately 375 man hours were devoted to those duties.
Briefs were provided on a number of occasions by the AFP on the nature and extent of their involvement in the investigations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 5 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Have the cassettes of `God Save The Queen/Advance Australia Fair' (National Anthem/National Song-joint cassette) been destroyed; if so, (a) why were they destroyed, and (b) what was the cost involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. (a) The proclamation by the Governor-General on 19 April 1984 of `Advance Australia Fair' as the National Anthem and `God Save The Queen' as the Royal Anthem meant that the cassettes issued under the Government's national symbols free-issue program to eligible organisations were incorrectly labelled.
(b) About 4,000 cassettes worth about $3,100 were destroyed in accordance with audit requirements. A cassette with a label identifying `Advance Australia Fair' as the National Anthem was substituted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On the basis of what information were searches carried out on the yacht Ouvea while it was on Norfolk Island.
(2) How much time was spent searching the yacht Ouvea for traces of explosives while it was on Norfolk Island.
(3) Was an inventory taken of the contents of the yacht Ouvea while it was being searched; if so, what items were recorded, and to whom was the resulting report forwarded.

(4) Were any traces of explosives discovered on the yacht Ouvea while it was on Norfolk Island, and was anything else found of which an onlooker might have said, It staggered me that they let them go, of the crew of the Ouvea.
(5) What scientific tests or analyses were carried out as a result of the examination of the yacht Ouvea on its return to Norfolk Island.

(6) Were any samples sent away from Norfolk Island for analysis; if so, under what arrangements, especially in relation to obtaining accurate results quickly, was this done; if not, what facilities on Norfolk Island were used to carry out testing.
(7) To whom was a summary of the findings of scientific analysis presented, and what were the major findings emphasised in such a report or reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information received from the New Zealand (NZ) Police.
(2) The search for explosives was undertaken as part of the search of the yacht-which took several hours.
(3) to (7) I refer the honourable senator to the answer given to Question No. 749. The AFP is not aware of specific action taken on differing aspects of the investigation by NZ authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 December 1985;

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the crew of the yacht Ouvea first demand that they either be charged or released and allowed to leave Norfolk Island if they so desired, and had their identification papers been subjected to exhaustive checking at that stage; if so, were the results of that checking available then.

(2) Had material for samples from the yacht been sent for thorough scientific analysis at that stage; if so, were those results already available, or was there a definite time by which they were expected.
(3) Who determined that there wasn't enough evidence to keep the crew of the Ouvea in custody.
(4) When did this occur.
(5) What legal or other advice was sought on this matter and from what quarter was it sought, if that did occur.
(6) What was the nature of any advice received, either before or after the release of the crew of the Ouvea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the completion of interviews, the crew of the Ouvea sought their release. The Police on Norfolk Island had no power to detain the crew while checks on the veracity of documents were made. Such enquiries normally take a considerable time.
(2) I refer the honourable senator to the answer given to Question No. 749. The AFP is not aware of specific action taken on differing aspects of the investigation by New Zealand (NZ) authorities.
(5) NZ Police on Norfolk Island consulted with NZ Police Headquarters and the Administrator of the Island.
(6) The advice was that there was insufficient evidence to justify continued detention of the crew.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 December 1985;

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When were identification papers in the possession of the crew first called for, after the return of the yacht Ouvea to Norfolk Island from New Zealand.
(2) Had these identification papers been examined when the Ouvea passed through Norfolk Island en route to New Zealand.
(3) Were the identification papers of the crew of the Ouvea referred beyond Norfolk Island for verification; if so, when was this done and at whose instigation.
(4) What time delay was expected in obtaining the result.
(5) When did it become clear that the crew were travelling on false documents.
(6) Where were the crew of the Ouvea when this information first came to light.

(7) What steps, if any, were taken to apprehend the crew if they were not in custody, or to assist the competent authorities in that regard if they were no longer within the jurisdiction of the Norfolk Island authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Upon their arrival, the crew of the Ouvea presented their papers to Norfolk Island Customs.
(2) Yes. They had been examined by Norfolk Island Customs.
(3) I refer the honourable senator to the answer given to Question No. 749. The AFP is aware that checks were instigated by New Zealand Police through Interpol.
(4) Any International enquiries invariably take a considerable time.
(5) On 26 July 1985, following enquiries through Interpol.
(6) The Australian Federal Police are not aware of the whereabouts of the crew at that time.
(7) On advice from New Zealand Police alerts were issued at Australian airports.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the Australian Federal Police established what happened to the yacht Ouvea after it left Norfolk Island on its return from New Zealand, if so, when did the yacht's crew disembark and under what circumstances did this occur; if not, was this matter investigated.
(2) Did the officers concerned succeed in tracing the yacht's whereabouts for any length of time, and when could the trail no longer be followed with certainty.

(3) Have the Australian Federal Police investigated the disappearance of 2 boats from Sydney marinas in the period just prior to the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior, if so, have any links between these events and the bombing operation in New Zealand been established, and what are those links.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Australian Federal Police have not established what happened to the Ouvea after it left Norfolk Island. They have not investigated this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was Dr Xavier Maniguet notified that the Australian Federal Police wished to interview him in Sydney, and how much notice was he given of the time of interview or of the matters of interest to the Australian Federal Police.
(2) Which people other than members of the Australian Federal Police were present during the questioning in Sydney of Dr Xavier Maniguet, and for what periods of time.

(3) If people other than French consular officials were present, in what capacity were they acting, and have steps been taken to ascertain whether such people are employees of the French defence services, or otherwise closely connected with those services; if so what facts have emerged in that regard.
(4) For what period of time was Dr Xavier Maniguet questioned, and over what matters did the questioning range.
(5) Did Dr Maniguet at any point demand either to be charged or to be released.
(6) Who made the decision that Dr Maniguet be allowed to leave.
(7) Was any advice sought beyond the Australian Federal Police in relation to the question of detention or release, if so, from whom was that advice sought, and when.
(8) When was the reply received and what did it say.
(9) Did Dr Maniguet subsequently seek to contact French authorities overseas before departure from Australia, and was he accompanied to the airport by any people when he was leaving.
(10) When did Dr Maniguet depart.
(11) Was further information about his role in the Rainbow Warrior bombing ascertained after his departure from Australia, and has any of this been forwarded to Interpol or other overseas bodies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dr Maniguet was notified by a New Zealand (NZ) Police Officer on the evening of 16 July 1985, that New Zealand Police wished to interview him. This was the first contact between police and Maniguet in relation to New Zealand enquiries.
(2) A New Zealand Police Officer conducted the interview of Maniguet at Australian Federal Police (AFP) Regional Headquarters in Sydney. The interview lasted about seven hours.
(3) Apart from Dr Maniguet and police officers no one else was present during the interview.
(4) See (2) above. The questions ranged over the sinking of the Ranbow Warrior, the passage of the Ouvea and other matters related to the New Zealand Police investigation.
(5) No. Dr Maniguet accompanied police voluntarily and gave a written statement.

(9) The AFP are not aware of any overseas contacts made by Dr Maniguet prior to his departure. After Dr Maniguet left AFP Regional Headquarters his activities were not monitored, save to confirm his departure from Australia.
(11) The AFP is unaware of any involvement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the ban by the Indian Government on the export of human bones seriously affect the teaching of anatomy to Australian medical students as claimed by Mr Ivan Meissner, University of New South Wales.

(2) Has the Government investigated the somewhat bizarre reports that human skeletons imported into Australia are frequently the result of the murder of children in India, and that up to 1,500 children a month are murdered for their skeletons.

(3) Will the Government give a categoric undertaking that if there is any truth in these reports at all, the Government will no longer import any human skeletons from any country where these heinous practices occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has advised the ban on the export of human skeletons imposed by the Indian Government is unlikely to have any effect on the teaching of anatomy in Australia. It is understood that in practice, most institutions do not import human skeletons at present but, instead, use models constructed largely from plastic for their undergraduate teaching. The Commission advised that institutions regard these as acceptable alternatives to human skeletons for teaching purposes.

(2) The Department of Foreign Affairs has advised that the Indian Minister for Home Affairs said on 18 December that according to information received from the Government of Bihar no instances of clandestine trade of human skulls has come to that Government's notice and consequently there was no question of conducting an inquiry into allegations about the export of children's skulls. In view of this information and of the ban imposed by the Indian Government of the export of human skeletons and parts thereof, the Australian Government does not propose to initiate further inquiries into the reports referred to by the honourable senator.

(3) Initial indications are that the Indian export prohibition has been effective. If evidence is presented which establishes that any country is prepared to trade in human remains obtained by such inhuman practices, the Australian Government will take steps to prohibit such imports into Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Office of National Assessments: Analysis of Rainbow Warrior Bombing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Office of National Assessments, either on its own initiative or under Ministerial directive, analysed the events surrounding the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior with a view to identifying steps that can be taken to minimise the risks of similar outrages occurring in Australian waters?
(2) Has the Office been able to benefit from information collected initially by friendly foreign intelligence organisations, if it has pursued work of this kind?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government normally declines to comment on confidential intelligence matters, including the work programs of agencies. In this case, because the Office of National Assessments does not have a protective security function, I am prepared to say that it has not undertaken any analysis of the findings surrounding the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior with a view to identifying steps that could be taken to minimise the risk of similar occurrences in Australia's waters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that from the Statistics produced for 1984-85 on the Compensation claims paid to public employees, one in three personnel in the Department of Defence Support had a successful compensation claim compared with 5.7 per cent of employees in the Department of Defence.
(2) Does this indicate that it was 8 times more dangerous to work in a government factory or ship yard than serve in the armed forces.
(3) What percentage of the Defence Department figures in terms of number of claims, and the payments involved were due to-
(1) members of the RAN;
(2) members of the Regular Army;
(3) members of the RAAF;
(4) members of the Reserve Forces; and
(5) civilian employees of the 3 Services and the central Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Annual Report of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation for 1984-85 has not yet been tabled, therefore, I am unable to provide the information requested. However, certain statistics are available for 1983-84 and these are provided in respect of that financial year.

(1) 1 in 4.68 (21.38%) personnel in Department of Defence Support had claims accepted where an initial compensation payment was effected during that year compared to 1 in 53.51 (1.87%) in respect of service and civilian personnel of Department of Defence.
(2) Whilst the figures may indicate that it is 11.43 times more dangerous to work in the Department of Defence Support than in the Department of Defence, this in fact is not the position.

In this respect it is important to note that serving members of the armed forces very rarely lodge a claim for compensation unless there is an immediate monetary gain. As these personnel receive full pay and allowances plus medical treatment as a condition of service, irrespective as to the cause of their injury or disease, they are not inclined to lodge a claim. This has the effect that virtually most injuries sustained by members under compensable circumstances do not result in claims unless a permanent disability exists.
It will be seen therefore, that the above figures do not reflect the true situation when comparing civilian versus armed forces employment for compensation statistical purposes.

(3) The number of claims submitted within each of the categories can only be established by manually searching in excess of 100,000 individual records and it is not proposed to direct the substantial manpower resources needed for this task.

Information in respect of the remaining portion of the question is available, other than that for members of the Reserve Forces whose payments are included with their respective Regular Force. Details are as follows:
Broadly, the above payments in respect of the regular armed forces can be categorised as follows:
(a) Serving Members. Payments being restricted to lump sums for permanent disabilities and to their dependants in respect of death of a member.
(b) Ex-Serving Members. Payments as for serving members plus weekly incapacity payments, medical and funeral expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1985 (Hansard, page 327), Senator Puplick asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister seen a Press Release issued by the Minister for Communications dated 28 August announcing that a new study is to be undertaken into television station ownership rules? Is it a fact that the terms of reference of the study direct it to have regard to `the Government's stated policy objectives?' Does the release go on in a footnote to record that these policy objectives are to be found in two Ministerial Press Releases and a speech to the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations? Why is it that the Government's stated policy objectives have not been outlined in a statement made to the Parliament but rather in media releases or speeches made outside Parliament? Will the Minister now ask his colleague to do this Parliament the courtesy of making such vital and significant policy statements to the Parliament itself where they can be debated in full?

Is it not a fact that the reason Parliament has not been favoured with a statement by Mr Duffy is that, if there is any severe embarrassment, it would be occasioned by the Minister trying to make a settlement about all the contradictory policies which so far he has only managed to dribble out in Press releases?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's policy objectives for broadcasting have been raised in the Parliament. There have been two major Statements regarding the development of broadcasting in Australia, particularly as it relates to the satellite. In the first of these Statements on 15 November 1983, I said that the central principles of our broadcasting policy are to maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services and to discourage concentration of ownership and control of stations, while maintaining the viability of the broadcasting system.
In its 1984 Satellite Program Services Report, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) identified five major policy concerns of successive governments:
(a) To maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services;
(b) To maintain the viability of the broadcasting system;
(c) to encourage an Australian look for television and radio by maintenance of an appropriate Australian content level and the fostering of an Australian production industry;
(d) To provide broadcasting services relevant and responsive to local needs; and
(e) To discourage concentration of media ownership and control of stations.

In a second Statement to the Parliament on 10 October 1984 I made explicit reference to this. I also pointed out that in this stage of development, the Government placed primary emphasis upon the need to extend services and to maximise diversity of choice for all Australians.

These issues were also dealt with in a report by the Forward Development Unit of my Department on Future Directions for Commercial Television. This report, which was publicly released on 9 July 1985, was distributed to all members of Parliament and was tabled in each House of Parliament on 21 August 1985.
The Press Release of 28 August 1985 was made in the context of these two previous Statements to Parliament and the FDU Report.
The Government is currently considering a package of measures for the equalisation of commercial television services in regional areas and an announcement will be made in due course.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Youth Employed in Australian Public Service

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 September 1985 (Hansard, page 501), Senator Harradine asked Senator Button, representing me as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, a question without notice concerning youth employed in the Australian Public Service. Senator Button undertook to provide additional factual information on the question.

ANSWER.PARA: I can now provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In his answer of 12 September Senator Button advanced various reasons, including changes to the Public Service Act, for the decline since the mid-1960s in the proportion of permanent officers of the Australian Public Service aged under 21 years.

Details regarding youth employment in the Australian Public Service are provided in an extensive statistical profile (covering the period 1951 to 1984) which was published in the Public Service Board's 1984-85 Annual Report. Analysis included in the profile indicates that the factors listed below have had a significant influence on the employment of youth as permanent officers in the Australian Public Service.

An increase in the proportion of youth completing final year high school has resulted in an increase in the average age of young people applying for and gaining appointment. This had led to a substantial decrease in the length of time youth appointees remain in the under 21 age group.

The proportion of young people electing to complete tertiary education before entering the workforce has increased, and more adults have been competing for base grade positions as competition for positions generally has intensified as a result of changes in the labour market and high rates of unemployment. These developments have affected the balance of youth and adult appointments.

Changes in Public Service Act provisions for permanent appointment have substantially increased the opportunities for adults, including women, to compete with young people for appointment to the Service. The most notable of these changes have been the abolition of discriminatory practices such as the `marriage bar' in 1966 and of age limits on appointments to Clerical/Administrative, Clerical Assistant and Typist vacancies.
There have been reductions in overall appointment rates in the Australian Public Service, due largely to constraints on the size of the Service and a decline in separation rates over recent years.
The effects of these developments have been countered in part by a decline in youth separation rates to almost the same level as overall separation rates. In 1966 they were much higher.
If present growth and application rates continue the Public Service Board expects that the proportion of youth at the end of this year will be slightly lower than in 1984.

Reference was made in the previous answer to the Government's decision to introduce youth traineeships in Commonwealth employment. We propose that the Commonwealth sector will take on 2,000 youth trainees, of whom 800 will be employed in the Australian Public Service. Youth traineeships will be based on temporary rather than permanent employment and the initial intake, while increasing the numbers of youth in Commonwealth employment, particularly 16 and 17 year olds, will not immediately affect permanent staff numbers. However, it is estimated that if, as expected, a high proportion of these trainees go on to permanent appointment (and if there is no change in Public Service growth rates) the proportion of youth in the Public Service will not diminish. We anticipate an increase in the following year when we expect to establish an increased number of traineeships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 September 1985 (Hansard, page 750), Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that in the United States of America there are now public telephones with which a long distance call can be made, the cost of that call can be charged to a credit card and the account of that credit card shows the cost of the call, the date and the phone number called? Has Telecom Australia any plans to introduce such telephones in Australia in the near future? If such details can so easily be shown on, say, a Visa account, how is it that Telecom intends to charge its customers for such a service.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

Yes. Telecom has been closely monitoring overseas developments of Card Phone systems. In August 1985 it invited design concept submissions from interested companies and is now examining the technical and commercial feasibility of introducing a Card Phone system in Australia on a trial basis in late 1986. No decision has been made at this stage on the charges to be applied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 October 1985 (Hansard, page 1094), Senator Sheil asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning: (1) The contribution of public service employment, employment creation and wage subsidy schemes, and increased education enrolments to the reduction in unemployment; and (2) The likely contribution of these factors to the projected reduction in unemployment for the coming year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
(1) The contribution of public service employment, employment creation and wage subsidy schemes, and increased education enrolments can be gauged from the following tables:
EMPLOYMENT BY SECTOR, LABOUR FORCE PARTICIPATION AND UNEMPLOYMENT
Government employment as proportion of total employment...
(a) ABS, Cat. No. 6248, `Wage and Salary Earners Australia' Comprises employees of Commonwealth, State and local government and semi-government authorities.
NUMBERS IN TRAINING OR EMPLOYMENT UNDER MAIN EMPLOYMENT AND WAGE SUBSIDY SCHEMES
Special Youth Employment Training Program (SYETP) and Adult WAge Subsidy Scheme (AWSS) averagea...
Source: Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.
(a) Number of persons on the respective programs at the end of each month averaged over the whole year.
FULL TIME STUDENTS AGED 15 YEARS AND OVER
(d) Preliminary. ABS, Cat. No. 4220 and preliminary estimates for non-government schools provided by the Department of Education
Table 1 shows that the rate of private sector employment growth was significantly greater than the rate of public sector employment growth in 1983-84 and 1984-85.

Additional public sector employment accounted for about 22 per cent of the increases in employment that occurred in both 1983-84 and 1984-85. In total, some 79,000 additional public sector jobs were generated over the period 1 July 1983 to 30 June 1985 while employment increased by 286,000 in the private sector. Since June 1985 the labour force surveys indicate that the growth rate of private sector employment has increased while public sector employment growth has eased.

Table 2 shows that the number of employment and wage subsidy schemes increased by around 30,600 between 1982-83 and 1983-84 but the total contribution of these schemes to employment stabilised in 1984-85. Since much of the additional employment created through these schemes was concentrated in employment programs in the public sector, a large part of the additional employment is reflected in the public sector's contribution to employment growth and unemployment reduction indicated in Table 1.

Table 3 indicates strong growth in full-time enrolments at schools and tertiary institutions. This reflects the Government's efforts to increase the access of Australian young people to education at these levels. The Government's objectives here are to raise the general level of occupational skills and educational attainment of those entering the labour market, and to provide more young people with a sound basis on which to develop a career. The increase in education participation will yield economic and other benefits both to the community and the young people concerned.

In summary, although the growth of public sector employment played an important part in the initial recovery of employment growth, the combined effect of public sector employment growth, wage subsidy and employment schemes, and increased education enrolments has been relatively small when compared with the total growth in employment over the past year.

(2) The relative contribution of public sector employment growth, employment and wage subsidy schemes, and increased education enrolments is likely to continue to decline over 1985-86. While total employment is projected to grow at about the same rate as last year (2 3/4 per cent):

public sector employment growth is likely to be lower (given that public expenditure is projected to grow at a lower rate-Commonwealth outlays, for example, are projected to increase by 1-3 per cent in real terms in 1985-86, compared with 6.1 per cent in 1984-85);
actual numbers in training or CEP employment are difficult to forecast, but approvals and placements under these schemes are planned to decline in 1985-86 (see Table 4 below); and
growth of tertiary education enrolments is expected to be maintained at around the current rate.
