(a) Due to lags between approvals and subsequent commencement, there can be major differences in data relating to approvals, placements and ``numbers in training'' for the same program. The latter figure is more relevant to aggregate employment. Table 4 has been included to indicate likely trends in 1985-86.
(b) Estimate. From 1 January 1986, an Integrated Wage Subsidy Program with a standard subsidy period of 6 months will replace SYETP and AWSS. Net of disabled and special needs job seekers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October 1985 (Hansard, pages 1400-1), Senator Richardson asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned agribusiness corporations and their effects on farmers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

The Minister considers that, notwithstanding the claims made in the article on agribusiness which appeared in the Financial Review on 26 August 1985, there are presently no grounds to warrant specific research into either agribusiness or the Namoi Co-operative.

The suggestion that agribusiness is in some way exploiting both producers and consumers implies that those involved are able to indulge in restrictive trade practices and therefore to extract excessive margins from both suppliers and consumers. While it is true that the size and degree of diversification of agribusiness firms has increased markedly in recent years, there is, to the minister's knowledge, no clear evidence of agribusiness companies having such power. The recent establishment of several new wool broking firms suggests, for instance, there there are no barriers to entry.
Nevertheless, the Minister is concerned that agribusiness should be conducted within a competitive environment and is therefore keeping a general oversight on developments.

In a broader context, the activities of agribusiness firms come under general review in the context of studies undertaken by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics concerning the efficiency of marketing operations in relation to particular products. Specific examples include studies on the marketing of dairy products and wool.

The Minister also points out that, should they consider it desirable, primary producers through co-operative and through statutory marketing authorities are able to work together to ensure that their particular interests are protected.

As a case in point, the Namoi Cotton Co-operative is a very good example of the benefits which can be derived from producers operating co-operatively in the production and marketing of their products.

In the case of the Namoi Cotton Co-operative, as is the general practice for co-operatives, surplus income is returned to members in the form of rebates. Retained earnings are directed into expansion of cotton processing facilities and into maintenance and improvement of existing facilities to the benefit of grower members and others using the Co-operatives' facilities.

Legislative responsibility for the establishment, control and supervision of co-operatives lies within the jurisdiction of State Governments. The Commonwealth therefore has no Constitutional authority to promote co-operatives. Nonetheless the Government is supportive of them. The Minister has indicated, for instance, that the Standing Committee of the Australian Agricultural Council, of which the Commonwealth is a member, has established a Working Party to undertake a study of co-operatives. The Working Party has wide terms of reference and is directed toward an assessment of the significance of co-operatives in Australian agriculture; a review of their legislative, financial and management structure; identifying any impediments to their successful operation; and making recommendations on any changes needed. The Namoi Cotton Co-operative will no doubt be taken in account in the Working Party's deliberations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 November 1985 (Hansard, page 1656), Senator Cook asked me a question without notice concerning the availability of any projections of wage increases which would have applied had the centralised wage fixing system been abandoned. I responded that as far as I knew the Government did not have a projection but undertook to seek any further response from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has provided the following response:

The Government has no formal projections of what wages growth would be in the event that the centralised wage fixing system was abandoned by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. However, there is no doubt that, in the context of the strong economic and employment growth that has been achieved under the Government's policies, a decentralised wage system would produce another wage explosion. Indeed, it was in recognition of the disastrous experience with more decentralised wage fixation arrangements in 1974 and 1981-82 that the Government developed the Prices and Incomes Accord with the ACTU, based on the return to a viable centralised wage system. Support for such a system is broad-based, having been endorsed at the National Economic Summit in April 1983 and supported since that time by both union and employer organisations.

The centralised wage system has ensured that economic recovery, with profitability restored and strong employment expansion, has not given rise to a resurgence of inflationary pressures which would undermine those gains. Instead, wage restraint has been achieved, as evidenced by the very low growth in earnings, of 4.0 per cent over the year to September 1985, the lowest increase since the mid-1960s. This contrasts dramatically with the experience during 1981-82 under the case-by-case approach to wage fixing when earnings growth peaked at 17 per cent per annum. A shift to a decentralised wage fixation system would see a resumption of conflict over sectional income claims, a resurgence of wage and price inflation and ultimately economic recovery would be aborted. For these reasons the Government opposes such a policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 November 1985 (Hansard page 2066-2067), Senator Reid asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning what she sees as an anomaly in the negative gearing and depreciation measures for rental properties announced by the Treasurer on 17 July 1985. Senator Reid referred to the situation where a taxpayer may be subject to quarantining but not attract depreciation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The terms of my announcement of 17 July 1985 are that residential income-producing buildings on which construction commenced on or before 17 July 1985 but which are sold after that date could, depending on the financing arrangements of the purchaser, be subject to the quarantining measure applicable to negative gearing but would not attract the new 4 per cent depreciation allowance.

Each new taxation measure brought forward by the Government must have a firm start-up date. The date of announcement, linked to the commencement date of construction of residential income producing buildings, was and remains the logical start-up date of the depreciation measure. That was the approach taken when depreciation allowances were announced on 21 August 1979 for short-term traveller accommodation and on 19 July 1982 for non-residential income-producing buildings.

While the availability of depreciation allowances will be of benefit to taxpayers who are in a negative gearing situation with their post-17 July 1985 residential income producing properties, the quarantining and depreciation measures should not be regarded as being completely intermeshed. During the transitional stage, there will be a number of possible outcomes for different taxpayers. For instance, property owners who are not negatively geared but the construction of whose rental property commenced after 17 July 1985 will not be affected by the quarantining measure but will still attract the depreciation allowance.

As with many taxation measures, it is inevitable that some taxpayers will gain no advantage from the depreciation allowances because they acted, in some cases, only days before the commencement date. Were the measure to be made retrospective or were new rules to be introduced regarding the stage of construction required for depreciation, there would always be particular taxpayers who only just failed to meet the eligibility requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2231), Senator Archer asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What inquiries have been instituted by either the Leader of the Government or the Special Minister of State concerning what was reported as a $50m drug haul bungle on the Sydney docks last week? Is there any allegation of either someone on authority deliberately causing the job to fail or conflict between Australian Federal Police Officers and Customs officers as to the administration of the duties concerned?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I have received a report on the matters raised by the Honourable Senator and while it would not be appropriate for me to comment on operational matters, I can say that both myself and the Special Minister of State have been informed that the container in which the drugs were secreted was properly handled by Australian Federal Police (AFP) and Customs officers in accordance with the provisions of the Customs Act.

We have further been advised that the retail value of the drugs in question was estimated at $16 million rather than the $50 million reported and we both confirm that there is no conflict between AFP and Customs officers in the administration of their duties relating to drug importations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November (Hansard, 2352 and 2353), Senator Parer and Senator Peter Rae asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, questions without notice on superannuation concerning firstly, the Transport Workers Union of Australia superannuation campaign and secondly any improvements to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme which might derive from the September Government/Australian Council of Trade Unions agreement. On 28 November Hansard, pages 2466 and 2467, Senator Crichton-Browne also raised the TWU superannuation campaign and Senator Chaney asked Senator Button, as the Leader of the Government, a question without notice concerning an agreement on superannuation in the paint industry.

ANSWER.PARA: To enable these questions on superannuation to be dealt with as a totality I have sought further information from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

In respect of superannuation for the Transport Industry, I convened a meeting on 15 November with representatives of the ACTU, TWU and road transport employers. Agreement was reached at that meeting that the parties would negotiate an appropriate superannuation scheme for the industry, consistent with the Government/ACTU agreement to apply from July 1986, and reflecting the outcome of the National Productivity case.
The ACTU/Government agreement which renegotiated the Accord provides for the introduction of superannuation in special and isolated circumstances prior to July 1986.

I have advised the parties in the transport industry that early implementation should only occur on a negligible cost basis consistent with the wage fixing guidelines and that there should be no industrial action.
Discussions between the parties in the industry are continuing consistent with the outcome of the 15 November meeting.

The other questions also concern the application of the Government/ACTU agreement in connection with superannuation. The September agreement provides for the outcome of the Productivity Case to be applied to public sector employees, as well as to the rest of the workforce. This could occur in a number of ways. Improved vesting, for example, would not increase the maximum retirement benefits available from the scheme.

As from 1 July 1986, superannuation arrangements for employees in the paint industry will provide for an industry superannuation scheme based on the outcome of the national productivity case. Members of the Federated Storemen and Packers' Union will be able to have the national productivity case outcome paid into the union's own superannuation scheme (Labour Unions Co-operative Retirement Fund), as an alternative to joining the industry scheme. The existing company superannuation schemes and the level of employer and employee contributions to those are to remain untouched.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2356) Senator Walters asked me, without notice, whether the Government would give a similar grant of $3000 to the Australian Flag Association to that given through the Office of Youth Affairs to enable young Australians to participate in the Ausflag '88 competition for a new national flag. I indicated that I suspected the answer was no, but that I would discuss it with the Prime Minister and then give Senator Walters a conclusive answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Minister Assisting me for Youth Affairs, the Honourable John Dawkins, wrote to the President of Australian National Flag Association, Sir Colin Hines, on 25 November 1985 replying in the following terms to a request for a similar grant to that given by the Office of Youth Affairs to Ausflag '88 to present the Australian National Flag Association's case for the retention of the present national flag.

``By way of background, you should know that the successful application by Ausflag 88 for a small grant from the International Youth Year (IYY) Secretariat, which is part of the Office of Youth Affairs, was determined on the basis that such support would enable young Australians to participate in a National Flag competition if they choose to do so.

IYY funds have supported many other non-profit organisations and groups to stage conferences, seminars, festivals and other activities which have involved issues of public concern and interest, and which were judged to contribute to broadening public debate.

The Commonwealth Government's aim in International Youth Year has been to encourage greater involvement of young people in such issues of the day through processes which stimulate thought, creativity and activity.

The decision to approve the grant to Ausflag '88 under these guidelines in no way reflects or indicates the Government's policy on the National Flag. As the Prime Minister stated in the House on 22 April 1985, the Government has no proposal before it to change the design of the National Flag.

Any request for a grant, therefore, from your Association would need to provide details of youth participation in the presentation of your case. Should your Association wish to pursue its request for a grant, you should make a detailed submission to the Office of Youth Affairs, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Edmund Barton Building, Barton, A.C.T. 2600 for consideration.''

I also answered a question in the House on 26 November where I stated that this Government has no intention of changing the existing Australian flag. (See House of Representatives Hansard, Page 3662, 26 November, 1985).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2609), Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that there is one roneoed copy of the report [on the operation of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, 1984-1985] in the Senate Records Office which honourable senators can look at but cannot take away and that, despite the fact that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs now has a reference to deal with this matter, neither members of that Committee nor the public can obtain copies of the report apparently until after Christmas.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Sub-section 93 (1) of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 requires the Attorney-General to prepare by 31 October 1985, a report on the operation of the Act for the year ending 30 June 1985, and to table that report within 15 sitting days of each House.
The annual report for 1984-1985 is a substantial document of 481 pages which was prepared and tabled in accordance with sub-section 93 (1) of the Act.

As printed copies were not available, copies of the report as tabled were made available in the Senate Records Office, the Bills and Papers Office, and the Parliamentary Library, in accordance with the usual practice.
Printed copies of the report were sent to honourable senators on 17 December 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1985 (Hansard, page 2777), Senator Sheil asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question with out notice concerning bans imposed on Mayne Nickless subsidiaries at Tullamarine which the company alleged were in connection with the Transport Workers Union superannuation campaign. I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has provided the following response:

I was aware of the dispute which affected Mayne Nickless operations at Tullamarine and other airports. The dispute related to industrial difficulties at a Mayne Nickless subsidiary in Canada. It appears that speculation that the industrial action related to superannuation was unfounded. All bans were lifted on 4 December as a result of progress in resolving the difficulties at the Loomis armoured car company in Vancouver which the Transport Workers Union stated its actions were directed towards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1985 (Hansard, page 2906), Senator Brownhill asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that farmers applying for diesel rebates have been told that their claims will not be processed until `procedural adjustments' have been made within the Australian Customs Service? Considering that this initiative was first determined prior to August and announced in the Budget on 20 August-some 3 1/2 months ago-does this not indicate at best inefficiency of a government department and at worst an attempt by government to avoid paying its bills at the expense of the Australian farmer and fisherman?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
The Government's decision to rebate the full excise duty on diesel fuel used in eligible primary production from 1 November 1985 required certain legislative amendments.

The necessary amendments were contained in the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which received the Royal Assent on 16 December 1985. Processing of claims for primary producers at the full rebate rate retrospective to 1 November 1985 was then immediately commenced by the Australian Customs Service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1985 (Hansard, page 3024), Senator Haines asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning vitamin B6.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

There has been long-standing concern by health authorities over the growing trend of healthy people taking unnecessary dietary vitamin supplements. This practice is being promoted by some sections of industry in parallel with unfounded allegations about nutritional deficiencies in the Australian food supply. My Department has been active in attempting to counter this trend through its many publications and magazine and journal articles on nutrition, and the Better Health Commission has identified nutrition as one of its major target areas.

The evidence now emerging of people taking megadoses of vitamins and developing illnesses which, in some cases are permanent and untreatable, is of considerable concern. Evidence on vitamin B6 such as that provided by Professor Truswell has been considered by the Poisons Schedule Committee (PSC) of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). Following its last meeting in late November 1985, the PSC is developing a recommendation for NHMRC endorsement. However, it has been hampered in its deliberations by the relative lack of objective scientific data on the safe daily intake of this vitamin.

It is known that the normal dietary requirement for good health in adults is 2-3 milligrams per day and that doses of 2000-3000 milligrams per day can lead to peripheral nerve disease. Because of the lack of data in the scientific literature on dose regimes between these extremes, industry has been asked by the PSC to provide evidence relating to safe dose levels.
The current situation is that there is no restriction on the sale of vitamin B6 and it is not listed in the NHMRC Uniform Poisons Schedule. The proposal which is being considered is as follows:
Where the recommended daily intake on the label is 50 milligrams or below, no restrictions need apply.
Where the recommended daily intake on the label is over 50 milligrams, then the preparation should either:
be placed in Schedule 4 of the Poisons Schedule and thus be available on a doctor's prescription only; or
carry a mandatory warning statement on the label as follows:
WARNING-THIS MEDICATION MAY BE BE DANGEROUS WHEN USED IN LARGE AMOUNTS OR FOR A LONG PERIOD
It is hoped to have a firm recommendation ready by the end of March 1986. This will then be passed to the State and Territory health authorities for them to amend their poisons regulations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 15 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: How many contracts awarded specifically under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act have been renegotiated after their original awarding (see answer to Question No. 12, Hansard, 13 May 1985, p. 1866 and specifically to part (3) thereof).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Contracting parties commonly alter the basis of their relationship if agreement can be reached. From time to time my Department has re-negotiated provisions of contracts awarded under the Airports (Business Concessions) Act. Variations are only agreed to by the Department of Aviation where they are deemed to be in the best interests of the Commonwealth.

Some of the areas in which variations to contracts have been made include the financial consideration payable, extent of goods and services offered, hours of operation, extent of leasehold improvements to be effected, pricing of goods and services and extension to the duration of contract itself.
There is no record kept of the number of contracts re-negotiated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 23 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware of responses to an advertisement placed in the Brisbane metropolitan press by a Brisbane man, Mr Paul Wells, in relation to the declining standards of Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) news and program presentations; if so, is the Minister prepared to refer the responses to a totally independent source for assessment, as a basis for reconsidering Board and senior management decisions on the so-called `new direction' of the ABC.

(2) Will the Minister review the structure, personnel and decision making processes of the current ABC Board, in view of the ABC's loss of audience support over recent program and format changes and the departure from the ABC of some of its key presenters and staff.
(3) Will general radio and television services to country areas be made more relevant to the particular needs and wishes of non-metropolitan viewers and listeners.

(4) Can the Minister assure ABC staff that further changes to ABC program style and format will not be undertaken without full consultation with senior production staff and that justification of such changes will be made, both publicly and internally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice received from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC):

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The advertisement placed by Mr Paul Wells was a private advertisement and no information on the outcome of the advertisement has been made available to the Minister. Similarly the ABC has received no information about the outcome of it.

(2) The Government established the new Corporation and appointed a new Board of Directors in the expectation that the ABC would be reformed and it is now midway through its most profound changes in fifty years. The Government supports the implementation of policies and strategies which are intended to lead to the development and improvement of the national broadcasting service. There is no intention to review the matters suggested by the honourable senator given the continuing steps for reform within the ABC.

(3) The ABC Board and Management are endeav- ouring to provide improved radio and television services which are both identifiably Australian and identifiably different from the programs offered by the commercial stations.

The Board has decided that in television the ABC should primarily be a national and state-based provider of programs, while in radio the introduction of the Second Regional Radio Network allows the ABC to extend its regional services as well as providing national and state radio services. The Board of Directors came to the conclusion that with the introduction of the domestic satellite many more services are likely to be available to regional areas through commercial television and this needed to be taken into account when planning the ABC's future directions as the national broadcasting service.

However, following the decision to phase out local regional television from Rockhampton and Townsville, the Corporation received a number of complaints from viewers living in affected areas. After a meeting in Townsville in early 1985 between ABC executives, Queensland politicians and representatives of civic and rural industry groups, an ABC committee of review was formed to see how the Corporation, given its current funding constraints, might best serve the people in North Queensland.

On 26 November 1985, the Committee presented to North Queensland Federal Parliamentarians a final draft version of its report on this matter and discussed at length the report's contents. The report will also be made available to the Queensland ABC Advisory Council. Comments and responses received from these groups will be considered before the ABC takes further action to finalise the report.
(4) These are not matters for the Minister but fall entirely within the province of the ABC especially in respect of programming style and format.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Community Services: Staff in Queensland

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 19 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the decision to base all of the 200 staff members allocated for the establishment of the Department of Community Services in Queensland in the Brisbane metropolitan area only been reviewed in view of the Government's policy of decentralisation.
(2) Is there now any possibility that some of these staff members will be allocated to serve in regional areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Department of Community Services has 378 staff in Queensland. Of these, 95 are located outside the Brisbane Metropolitan area. 87 of these non-metropolitan staff are located in north Queensland, mainly in Townsville. There are also Regional Rehabilitation Units at Maroochydore and Toowoomba. The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) regional presence is to be extended in Queensland with the planned opening of a unit at the Gold Coast in the first half of 1986. Additional non-metropolitan CRS units in Queensland are under consideration.

The Department is examining the desirability and feasibility of establishing a broader regional capacity with a view to greater community involvement in the planning and delivery of child care, residential and community care programs.

In developing this strategy, I am aware of the need to give access to the department and its programs to all community groups, including those in non-metropolitan areas. I am also aware of the importance of improved co-ordination and consultative arrangements with State and local governments in the identification of needs within the community and the development of proposals to meet those needs. Consideration of any proposals in this area will be addressed initially in the context of the 1986-87 Budget deliberations.

I should also mention that the Department will shortly be calling for applications from external research bodies to undertake a study of the access to and delivery of community services in remote communities. This project will be funded under the new Community Services Research and Development Fund for which funds were provided in the 1985-86 Budget. The project will provide valuable input to the development of policies affecting remote and isolated communities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum is allocated in the current financial year for hospitality/entertainment which may be expended:
(a) by the Department; and
(b) by each and every Statutory Authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(2) What were the guidelines in force as at 1 September 1985 for expenditure from the hospitality/entertainment account of:
(a) the Department; and
(b) each and every Statutory Authority for which the Minister has responsibility.
(3) Following upon the Statement by the Treasurer `Reform of the Australian Taxation System' on 19 September 1985, what action is proposed in relation to questions 1 and 2.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) Australian Audit Office-$6,000; Australian Bicentennial Authority, State and Northern Territory Offices, Commonwealth provision-$25,000; Allocation for ACT and Island Territory Office-$2,000; Allocation for National Office-$29,000; Australian Science and Technology Council-$2,000; Commonwealth Ombudsman-$1,200; Economic Planning Advisory Council-$5,000; Merit Protection and Review Agency-$2,400; Office of National Assessments-$9,500; Public Service Board-$10,000.

(b) Australian Bicentennial Authority-Hospitality and entertainment expenditures are oversighted by Executive Directors at State level and by General Managers at the National Office. Official entertainment is undertaken on a limited and necessary basis only.
(3) Entertainment expenditure is being recorded in accordance with Finance Circular 1985/18. The Australian Bicentennial Authority also is complying with the Statement by the Treasurer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the distribution of the collections amongst the States from the operation of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 take into account the following-
(a) the existing states of the roads;
(b) the climate of the area;
(c) special weather conditions; and
(d) other factors.
(2) Has there been any work as yet on a distribution formula.
(3) Will Federal registration fees be payable by all Government Trading Authorities, State and Federal.
(4) Is there provision for anything less than full recovery; if so, where is this provision in the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 23 (3) of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 specifies that the distribution of payments from the Trust Fund to the States should reflect the damage done to each State's roads by registered motor vehicles and trailers operating under the Act. Accordingly, to the extent that they impact on road damage, such factors as those referred to in the question will be taken into account.
(2) Yes. Preliminary work has been commenced by the Federal Department of Transport but a formula has not yet been determined.
(3) All non-exempt Government Trading Authorities will be subject to the provisions of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985.

(4) Section 5 (3) of the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985 provides that registration charges may recover no more than the road maintenance and upkeep costs resulting from damage done by registered motor vehicles or trailers. Subject to that constraint there is no legislative requirement which determines the rate of cost recovery that will be achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What degree of approval by the States, under the provisions of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 will be necessary before the Minister for Transport would pronounce `substantial agreement' and have the legislation proclaimed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As I have indicated on a number of occasions, a decision that the States and Territories have made substantial progress in implementing their parts of the fast-track package of reforms for the road transport industry will not be taken until I have fully consulted with industry and my Ministerial colleagues on the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC).

This decision will be taken in the context of the unanimous agreement of all Federal, State and Territory Governments at ATAC in December 1985 to aim for a target implementation date for the fast-track package of 1 July 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian National Railways actually reduced freight rates by 20 per cent between Adelaide and Alice Springs; if so, is any action proposed to restore the previous levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) has advised that freight rates between Adelaide and Alice Springs have been reduced by 20 per cent on piggyback units with a gross weight of 32 tonnes. This represents about one per cent of AN's piggyback traffic on this route. Rate reductions for the remaining piggyback traffic and container traffic on this route have been around 9 per cent.
The rate reductions are part of AN's commercial strategy and are made possible as a result of increased efficiency achieved from AN's new intermodal wagons and loading facilities.
As with all other commercial decisions, AN rates are continuously monitored and adjusted twice yearly in the light of prevailing market conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the levels of State Railway Charges as yet been given broad and general discussions by State and Federal Authorities.

(2) What discussion and participation will the Tasmanian Government have under the provisions of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985, as to the fixing of the Tasmanian Rail Freight and what guarantees will be given to Tasmania on the future of the Rail service if the actions of the Government as to freight levels prejudice its economic viability.

(3) Will States which have special major contracts such as coal, iron ore, timber and wheat be compelled to raise those rates to meet the requirements the Minister for Transport referred to in his speeches but which are not covered by the legislation.
(4) What action does the Minister have at his disposal to obtain agreement and does the implementation of this whole legislation depend on gaining increases in rail freight rates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All parts of the fast-track package, including the need to improve interstate rail cost recovery have been discussed by State and Federal authorities.

(2) The arrangements with respect to the Tasmanian rail system are governed by the provisions of the Tasmanian rail transfer agreement. The Government has recently completed a three year agreement with the Australian National Railways Commission on the operation of Tasrail and the performance of Tasrail will be reviewed towards the end of that period.

(3) Most contracts relating to the carriage of major commodities such as coal, iron ore, timber and wheat relate to intrastate operations and therefore are not directly affected by the rail costs recovery objective identified as part of the fast-track package.

(4) Improvement in interstate rail cost recovery can be achieved by either increasing revenue, reducing costs or some combination of both. All State Ministers with responsibility for railways have agreed that the cost recovery of interstate railway operations should be improved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been a Departmental or Australian Transport Advisory Council Impact Study done of the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985.
(2) What projections does the Minister for Transport have as to-
(a) the projected increases to Road Freight rates (per tonne/km) and/or percentage;
(b) the projected percentage increase in rail freights;
(c) the effects on large, medium and small operators, respectively;
(d) the effects this would have on business failure in each group;
(e) the effects on the subcontractors; and
(f) the cost of implementation of the requirement on a per truck/ per operator basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Government in drawing up the fast-track package of reforms for the road transport industry took into consideration the impact the package would have on the industry as well as the economy as a whole.

Around one dollar in seven, or approximately $25 billion each year, is spent on transport in Australia. In these terms the additional $14m each year to be raised by the interstate road transport legislation is miniscule.

In most long distance work in Australia the market price for transport is determined by vehicles on full State registration so the impact of the interstate vehicle charge on freight rates would be negligible. However, at the very most, where some goods are mainly carried by interstate vehicles, any increase on the price of transporting these goods is estimated not to exceed half a per cent.
Against these cost factors there will be offsetting savings as a result of the other elements of the fast-track package, eg.
reduced road accident costs resulting from the introduction of graduated driver licensing and the removal of the speed limit differential between trucks and other vehicles outside built-up areas
lower financing costs as the finance industry perceives the improvements in the professionalism and viability of the road transport industry

improved consumer protection for owner-drivers and operator licensing will lead to better informed entrants to the industry therefore reducing the risks of early financial failure for which the community pays one way or another
improved productivity resulting from more efficient operating conditions.

(b) Matching improvements in interstate railway cost recovery is an integral part of the fast track package. The measures to be adopted in improving the financial performance of each rail system including the question of increased rail freight rates is a matter for individual Governments and rail systems to determine and is subject to examination by the Inter-State Commission which is due to report by 30 April 1986.
(d) A worthwhile reduction in business failure is expected as the interstate road transport legislation is implemented as part of the fast-track package of reforms for the road freight industry.

(f) There has been a net increase of one senior executive in the average operative staffing level of the Federal Department of Transport associated with the implementation of the Federal interstate registration scheme. Other minor administrative costs incurred by the Federal Department of Transport have been met within existing allocations. On a per truck/per operator basis these costs are negligible.

Ongoing costs for the Federal interstate vehicle registration scheme will be minimised by utilising existing State agencies which already register interstate vehicles. The States and Territories will continue to impose prescribed fees to a maximum of $100 to recover the marginal administrative costs of operating the scheme.
Similarly the operator licensing scheme is to be administered by State and Territory Governments with provision for appropriate fees to be collected to cover marginal expenses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken, or are proposed, to cover the objections in regard to the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 raised by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport wrote to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on 18 October 1985 outlining the Government's position in relation to matters the Committee raised concerning the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985. Subsequently the Government agreed to an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats which covered the Committee's concerns regarding the need for a legislative ceiling to be placed on interstate vehicle registration charges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Fremantle Port area between latitude 31.46S-32.04S and longitude 115.34E-115.44E, within the limits of the Australian Territorial Sea; if not, how is this area designated.
(2) Is Australia a signatory to the:
(a) International Convention of Safety of Life at Sea (1974);
(b) United Nations Convention of the Territorial Sea and Contiguous Zone; and
(c) International Association of Lighthouse Authorities (IALA) through the International Maritime Organization (IMO).
(3) Are the following sentences contained in the documents listed in Question 2 and/or the Acts covering these conventions:

(a) Safety of Life at Sea 1974: (i) each contracting Government will take all steps necessary to ensure that when intelligence of any of the dangers specified in paragraph (a) of this regulation is received, it will be promptly brought to the knowledge of those concerned;

(b) Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 (UN Convention of Territorial Sea and Contiguous Zone: (ii) the Coastal State is required to give appropriate publicity to any dangers to navigation of which it has knowledge within its territorial sea; and
(c) IALA: (iii) confirmation that the buoyage changes in specific areas have been carried out will normally be announced in radio navigational warnings and in notice to mariners.
(4) Is it the responsibility of the Minister for Transport through his Departmental Federal Sea Surveillance and Safety Centre to authorise such warnings to all concerned; if not, why not.

(5) Does the Minister through his Department believe that due to a letter from Prime Minister, Mr J. A. Lyons to the States dated 3 July, 1934, coded AK 3/10/2, which makes no mention of radio warnings or the responsibility of warning all concerned of dangers, etc., as do the Acts and Conventions mentioned in Questions 2 and 3 that the Department of Transport is relieved from sending out warnings to all those concerned.

(6) Does the Minister deny his responsibility under the following Acts: Coastal Waters (State Title) Act 1980 and Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 which clearly state that all responsibility for international agreements are retained by the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Department of Marine and Harbours, Western Australia, advises that the Port of Fremantle includes inner and outer harbours and the respective water area.

The inner harbour is all that situated within the mouth of the Swan River extending from a line at the western extremity of the north and south moles to the western alignment of the Fremantle traffic bridge.

The outer harbour is bounded by a line starting at a point on the sea coast of the mainland in latitude 31*56'22''S thence extending northwesterly on a true bearing of 341 degrees to the intersection of latitude 31*46'S thence due west to intersect the meridian of longitude 115*30'E thence due south to intersect latitude 31*57'S thence due east to intersect the meridian of longitude 115*34'E thence southerly to latitude 32*04'S thence south easterly to Entrance Point, Garden Island, thence along the high water mark of the northern, eastern and southern shores of that island to South West Point. Thence southerly to John Point on the mainland. Thence easterly and northerly along the high water mark to the eastern extremity of the South Mole (excluding the Fremantle Fishing Boat harbour), thence along the southern side of the South Mole to the latter's western extremity, then west north westerly to the western extremity of the mole, thence along the northern side of the north mole to the latter's eastern extremity at the high water mark of such ocean and then northerly along that mark to the starting point.

A small segment of the south westerly waters of the outer harbour lie within the Australian territorial sea. Of the waters north of latitude 31*56'22''S some are within the territorial sea and others in areas of high seas.
(2) (a) Yes. Australia acceded to the International Convention of Safety of Life at Sea on 17 August 1983.
(b) Yes. Australia acceded to the International Convention of the Territorial Sea and Contiguous Zone on 14 May 1963.
(c) No. Australia, through the Federal Department of Transport, is a member of the International Association of Lighthouse Authorities which is a non-Government consultative body.

Australia is a member of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) having acceded to the Convention of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization (as it was then known) on 13 February 1952.
(b) Yes. However this does not prevent co-operative arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth concerning the implementation of this provision.
(c) No document containing the sentence quoted has been identified by the Department of Transport.

(4) The Minister for Transport through his Departmental Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre authorises warnings of dangers to navigation which relate to those areas for which the Federal Government accepts responsibility as part of a shared responsibility with the States and Territories for the provision of marine navigational aids.
(5) Yes. The Department of Transport is only required to send out warnings of dangers to navigation in relation to those parts of the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible.
(6) The Coastal Waters (State Title) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 assign no specific ministerial responsibility.

Section 6 of both Acts states, Nothing in this Act affects the status of the territorial sea of Australia under international law or the rights and duties of the Commonwealth in relation to ensuring the observance, in relation to that sea or any other waters, of international law, including the provisions of international agreements binding on the Commonwealth and, in particular the provisions of the Convention on the Territorial Sea and the Contiguous Zone relating to the right of innocent passage of ships.
This provision does not prevent co-operative arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth concerning implementation of international maritime agreements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 2 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Aviation advise why there has been a cut-back in funds for locally owned airport maintenance.
(2) What impact will this decision have on air safety, particularly in isolated areas where small local authorities have limited funds to allocate to airport maintenance.
(3) What standards are set by the Department of Aviation to ensure that local airports meet required safety levels.
(4) How can these safety levels be guaranteed if local authorities cannot meet additional costs associated with airport maintenance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No actual reduction for routine maintenance has occurred. However, in October last year, aerodrome owners were advised that the level of funding for this financial year was to be reduced. Since then, the Minister for Aviation has directed his Department to make additional funds available to enable all properly substantiated claims for routine aerodrome maintenance to be met. Urgent specific maintenance projects will also be funded.

(2) The level of funds has been restored and there will be no impact on air safety. Even if it had been necessary to restrict maintenance grants, safety would not have been compromised although a reduction in air services may have been necessary.

(3) The Department of Aviation adopts airport standards generally in accordance with recommendations of the International Civil Aviation Organisation. All licensed aerodromes are subject to regular inspection by Department of Aviation officers who ensure that these physical standards continue to be met.

(4) Local authorities will now receive sufficient maintenance subsidies in this financial year to keep their aerodromes at the required standard. Safety levels at licensed Australian aerodromes are always closely monitored. If a local authority were unable to generate sufficient finance to maintain an aerodrome at a specific standard, then action may be necessary to de-license it or to maintain it at a standard only suitable for smaller aircraft by such measures as reduction in runway strip dimensions.
